Racial Disparity: Substance Dependency and Psychological Health Problems among Welfare Recipients

Author: Lee, Kyoung Hag1; Hines, Lisa D1 School of Social Work, Wichita State University, 1845 Fairmount St., Wichita, KS 67260-0154, USA kyoung.lee@wichita.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 207-219.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142150?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explored the racial disparity of substance dependency and psychological health among White, African American, and Hispanic Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (TANF) recipients as well as the relationship between substance dependency and psychological health. It analyzed 1,286 TANF recipients from the 2006 National Survey on Drug Use and Health data. Analysis of variance indicated that Whites were experiencing more nicotine and alcohol dependency and psychological distress than others, but African Americans and Hispanics were experiencing more cocaine dependency than Whites. Ordinary least squares regression revealed that nicotine dependency is significantly related to the psychological distress of Whites. Alcohol dependency is significantly associated with the psychological distress of three groups. Culturally competent programs are suggested. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Racial+Disparity%3A+Substance+Dependency+and+Psychological+Health+Problems+among+Welfare+Recipients&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Kyoung+Hag%3BHines%2C+Lisa+D&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Kyoung&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=207&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.776322

Free Solar Lanterns to Below Poverty Line Girls in India: A Step Toward Achieving Millennium Development Goals

Author: Garg, Rajesh11 Department of Community Medicine, V.C.S.G. Government Medical Sciences & Research Institute, Srinagar-Garhwal, Uttrakhand, India garg50@rediffmail.com

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 189-195.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142155?accountid=14667

Abstract: Development sectors like health cannot function in isolation. Intersectoral coordination between various departments helps in bringing a positive change in the health-seeking behavior of society in the long run. The decision by the Government of India to provide free solar lanterns (lamps) to the school-going girls of below poverty line families is a welcome step in this context. This initiative would help in reducing the number of school dropout girls and thus help in improving the health indicators that are directly related to women's education. Thus it is an initiative that will help in attainment of Millennium Development Goals through women's education and empowerment. Along with that, the environment-friendly approach will definitely have an impact on health of the girls by switching from kerosene/wood stoves to solar lantern light. Also this initiative would pave the path of real 'intersectoral coordination' in the health sector in India that is marred with watertight functioning of various departments. There is an urgent need to popularize the scheme and involve different stakeholders like corporate houses, media, nongovernment organizations, multinational welfare agencies, and local governing bodies for ensuring the availability and utilization of solar lanterns in India. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Free+Solar+Lanterns+to+Below+Poverty+Line+Girls+in+India%3A+A+Step+Toward+Achieving+Millennium+Development+Goals&amp;rft.au=Garg%2C+Rajesh&amp;rft.aulast=Garg&amp;rft.aufirst=Rajesh&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=189&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.775047

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Free+Solar+Lanterns+to+Below+Poverty+Line+Girls+in+India%3A+A+Step+Toward+Achieving+Millennium+Development+Goals&amp;rft.au=Garg%2C+Rajesh&amp;rft.aulast=Garg&amp;rft.aufirst=Rajesh&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=189&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.775047

The Integrated Behavioral Health Service Delivery System Model

Author: Wodarski, John S11 College of Social Work, The University of Tennessee, Knoxville, 324 Henson Hall, Knoxville, TN 37996, USA jwodarsk@utk.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 301-317.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142193?accountid=14667

Abstract: Costs and effective management of health care in general, and behavioral health care in particular, have been of primary importance and concern to federal, state, and local governments. With the passage of Health Care Reform (HCR) these concerns will only escalate. Thus, the necessity for the development of innovative, successful, and integrated cost-effective treatments and procedures is evident. The behavioral health care model presented here is proposed to address these needs. The model centers on the composition of effective psychosocial treatment and provides a cost analysis of social work and its services. By defining the problems that need to be addressed in health care management and cost containment, and applying findings of evidence-based studies, this article provides an effective model for health care organizations. It also presents a profile of the behavioral health social worker, defining the requisite abilities for effectiveness in the role and looking at the key impact areas for a behavioral health model. This comprehensive guide will prepare new social workers entering health care organizations as well as provide a valuable reference for existing social workers, academics, and practitioners of behavioral health care. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Integrated+Behavioral+Health+Service+Delivery+System+Model&amp;rft.au=Wodarski%2C+John+S&amp;rft.aulast=Wodarski&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=301&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2011.622243

Complex Lives: Resiliency of African American Women with HIV/AIDS Serving as Informal Kinship Care Providers

Author: Stokes, Charu11 Graduate School of Social Work, Boston College, Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, USA; LICSW, 140 Commonwealth Ave., Chestnut Hill, MA 02467, USA stokesca@bc.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 285-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142208?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using the resiliency model as a framework, this qualitative description study was designed to elicit the experiences of African American women living with HIV/AIDS serving as informal kinship care providers. Themes emerging from the interviews included (a) strengths of informal social supports, (b) benefits of living with HIV as opposed to women who are not HIV positive, and (c) negative experiences of child welfare services. Findings suggest a plethora of resources women accessed through community-based agencies because of their HIV/AIDS status, as opposed to child welfare agencies. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Complex+Lives%3A+Resiliency+of+African+American+Women+with+HIV%2FAIDS+Serving+as+Informal+Kinship+Care+Providers&amp;rft.au=Stokes%2C+Charu&amp;rft.aulast=Stokes&amp;rft.aufirst=Charu&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=285&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.872411

The Role of Cultural Proverbs and Myths in Shaping Sexual Worldviews of Adolescents in Botswana: Evidence from an HIV/STD Prevention Research Study

Author: Malinga-Musamba, Tumani1; Ntshwarang, Poloko N1 Social Work Department, University of Botswana, Private Bag UB 00705, Gaborone, Botswana

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 232-239.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142225?accountid=14667

Abstract: The literature has shown that adolescents are exposed to socio-cultural activities that put them at risk of HIV and other sexually transmitted infections. To develop effective intervention strategies and programs, it is imperative to understand how the cultural proverbs and myths create sexual norms and shape the worldview of adolescents. The findings indicate that some cultural proverbs and myths negatively influence adolescents hence expose them to risky sexual behaviors. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Cultural+Proverbs+and+Myths+in+Shaping+Sexual+Worldviews+of+Adolescents+in+Botswana%3A+Evidence+from+an+HIV%2FSTD+Prevention+Research+Study&amp;rft.au=Malinga-Musamba%2C+Tumani%3BNtshwarang%2C+Poloko+N&amp;rft.aulast=Malinga-Musamba&amp;rft.aufirst=Tumani&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=232&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.776394

Urbanization as a Determinant of Health: A Socioepidemiological Perspective

Author: Patil, Rajan R11 School of Public Health, SRM University, Chennai, India; Division of Epidemiology, School of Public Health, SRM University, Potheri, Kattankulathur-603203 Greater Chennai, India rajanpatil@yahoo.com

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 335-341.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142276?accountid=14667

Abstract: Urbanization is a process that leads to the growth of cities due to industrialization and economic development and that leads to urban-specific changes. Urbanization is associated with profound changes in diet and exercise that in turn increase the prevalence of obesity with attendant increases in risk of type II diabetes and cardiovascular disease. The growing burden of disease among vulnerable populations and pervasive socioeconomic inequities within urban systems exaggerates the adverse impacts of urbanization on health. More than one half of children younger than age 5 of urban poor are stunted and/or underweight. More than one half of the child births occur at home, in slums, putting the life of the mother and newborn in serious risk. Inadequate reach of services due to illegality, social exclusion of slums, hidden slum pockets, and weak social fabric have resulted in a rapid proliferation of the unqualified private health sector, leading to high health expenditures and continuing a vicious cycle of poverty and ill health in urban slums. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Urbanization+as+a+Determinant+of+Health%3A+A+Socioepidemiological+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Patil%2C+Rajan+R&amp;rft.aulast=Patil&amp;rft.aufirst=Rajan&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=335&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.821360

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Urbanization+as+a+Determinant+of+Health%3A+A+Socioepidemiological+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Patil%2C+Rajan+R&amp;rft.aulast=Patil&amp;rft.aufirst=Rajan&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=335&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.821360

Ryan White CARE Act Part D: Matches and Gaps in Political Commitment and Local Implementation

Author: Hernandez, Julieta P1; Potocky, Miriam1 School of Social Work, Florida International University, Miami, Florida, USA; University of Miami, Miller School of Medicine, Pediatrics, Mailman Center for Child Development, 1601 NW 12 Ave., Room 4055 (D-820), Miami, FL 33136, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 29, Iss. 3-4,  (0, 2014): 267-284.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142303?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article demonstrates the opportunities for and challenges of the Ryan White Comprehensive AIDS Resources Emergency (CARE) Act Part D to implementing its mandate for comprehensive family-centered systems of care for women, infants, children, and youth with HIV/AIDS. Part D legislation should promote practices addressing families with models for basic security, judiciously embrace those universal public health policies aiming to improve children's overall welfare, and consistently repudiate those policies infringing on human rights of women infected with HIV, or ignoring their children's basic needs. The proposed revisions to Part D implementation may renew its political commitment to serving the needs of families who are HIV affected. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Ryan+White+CARE+Act+Part+D%3A+Matches+and+Gaps+in+Political+Commitment+and+Local+Implementation&amp;rft.au=Hernandez%2C+Julieta+P%3BPotocky%2C+Miriam&amp;rft.aulast=Hernandez&amp;rft.aufirst=Julieta&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=29&amp;rft.issue=3-4&amp;rft.spage=267&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2013.821350

Service Approaches for Youths Who Commit Sexual Crimes: A Call for Family-Oriented Models

Author: Yoder, Jamie Rae

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 360-372.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018529?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sexual crimes committed by youths are a major social concern. Currently, adult-based models of service delivery are applied to juveniles with very little evidence to support treatment effectiveness. With prevailing limitations to these approaches, consideration of methods for improving services to youths is warranted. Adapting traditional treatment approaches to incorporate family-oriented models of service delivery is likely to improve youth and family outcomes. The goal of this article is twofold: (1) to review the state of the evidence of current treatments for sexually abusive youths, identifying gaps in services and research, and (2) to suggest service improvements by incorporating family treatment approaches and reviewing the extant evidence for existing family-oriented models. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Service+Approaches+for+Youths+Who+Commit+Sexual+Crimes%3A+A+Call+for+Family-Oriented+Models&amp;rft.au=Yoder%2C+Jamie+Rae&amp;rft.aulast=Yoder&amp;rft.aufirst=Jamie&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=360&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897108

____________________________________________________________

Understanding convergence and divergence: old and new cleavages in the politics of minimum income schemes in Italy and Poland

Author: Jessoula, Matteo; Kubisa, Julia; Madama, Ilaria; Zielenska, Marianna

Publication info: Journal of International and Comparative Social Policy  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (January 2014): 128-146.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018572?accountid=14667

Abstract: Italy and Poland present similarly weak minimum income protection models, yet this results from two different policy trajectories in the last 15 years: both countries actually introduced a minimum income scheme (MIS) between the late 1990s (Italy) and the early 2000s (Poland), but later developments were characterized by policy reversal in the Italian case vis-a-vis institutionalization in Poland. The paper therefore addresses two intertwined puzzles. First, in the light of very different background conditions, which factors help understand the convergent process towards the introduction of MIS? Second, what explains remarkable divergence in the subsequent phase? Challenging previous claims about the limited scope of political competition dynamics in the field of social assistance, due to generally narrow constituencies and limited political mobilization, we contend that political competition dynamics are key factors in order to make sense of both convergent and divergent trajectories in the two diverse phases. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+convergence+and+divergence%3A+old+and+new+cleavages+in+the+politics+of+minimum+income+schemes+in+Italy+and+Poland&amp;rft.au=Jessoula%2C+Matteo%3BKubisa%2C+Julia%3BMadama%2C+Ilaria%3BZielenska%2C+Marianna&amp;rft.aulast=Jessoula&amp;rft.aufirst=Matteo&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=128&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.936024

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+convergence+and+divergence%3A+old+and+new+cleavages+in+the+politics+of+minimum+income+schemes+in+Italy+and+Poland&amp;rft.au=Jessoula%2C+Matteo%3BKubisa%2C+Julia%3BMadama%2C+Ilaria%3BZielenska%2C+Marianna&amp;rft.aulast=Jessoula&amp;rft.aufirst=Matteo&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=128&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.936024

____________________________________________________________

Running out of road? Dilemmas and issues for the British Labour Party and the Swedish Social Democratic Party in their search for a 'modern' welfare state narrative

Author: Page, Robert M

Publication info: Journal of International and Comparative Social Policy  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (January 2014): 107-126.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018583?accountid=14667

Abstract: Following significant electoral defeats in 2010, both the British Labour Party and the Swedish Social Democratic Party (SAP) have been re-considering their approach to the welfare state. This article outlines some of the key themes of social democracy and social democratic social policy before discussing the evolution of the latter in both Sweden and Britain. The paper explores the cumulative effect of the revisionist approaches adopted by both parties over time which has resulted in a distancing from a welfare state strategy based on equality, universalism and publicly provided services. It is concluded that both parties now have little road left to construct a modern welfare state narrative that reflects 'core' social democratic principles. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Running+out+of+road%3F+Dilemmas+and+issues+for+the+British+Labour+Party+and+the+Swedish+Social+Democratic+Party+in+their+search+for+a+%27modern%27+welfare+state+narrative&amp;rft.au=Page%2C+Robert+M&amp;rft.aulast=Page&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=107&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.921234

____________________________________________________________

Peer Discussion and Client Motivation in Men's Domestic Violence Programs: An Australian Qualitative Interview Study

Author: Gray, Rebecca; Lewis, Pamela; Mokany, Tibor; O'Neill, Brian

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 390-404.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018595?accountid=14667

Abstract: Relationships Australia NSW and Baptist Community Services NSW & ACT, through its BCS LifeCare Counselling & Family Services program, collaborated to explore client perceptions of men's domestic violence programs. Recruitment targeted male clients and their female partners, across six locations in New South Wales, Australia. In total, 63 qualitative interviews were gathered from 28 participants, between 2007 and 2009, at program intake, program completion and 6-month follow-up. The focus of this article is on the 20 male interviews conducted with 14 participants at program completion (10) and at 6-month follow-up (10). Recurring themes from these interviews indicate the potentially disruptive effect of client dialogue on group dynamics. While positive group discussion has the potential to enhance client motivation, negative peer discussions, external to group sessions, can diminish group functioning and client motivation for these participants. The paradoxical nature of the group-intervention experience is explored in light of these accounts. Suggestions for men's domestic violence program facilitation and research are outlined. Adapted from the source document.

Convergence from below? The reform of minimum income protection in France and the UK

Author: Clegg, Daniel

Publication info: Journal of International and Comparative Social Policy  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (January 2014): 147-164.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018747?accountid=14667

Abstract: Through a systematic comparison of major reforms to minimum income benefits for people of working age in France and the UK, this paper assesses the scope for cross-national convergence in this growing sector of European welfare states. It shows that while differing institutional legacies have shaped the precise design of the new minimum income systems that have been put in place on each side of the Channel in recent years, there is also evidence of an increasingly common conceptualisation of the function of the last safety net and its articulation with the labour market, despite the two countries' still very different political economies. This suggests the potential across welfare states for convergence 'from below' on broader understandings of the role of social security provisions in regulating economic life. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Convergence+from+below%3F+The+reform+of+minimum+income+protection+in+France+and+the+UK&amp;rft.au=Clegg%2C+Daniel&amp;rft.aulast=Clegg&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.938683

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Convergence+from+below%3F+The+reform+of+minimum+income+protection+in+France+and+the+UK&amp;rft.au=Clegg%2C+Daniel&amp;rft.aulast=Clegg&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.938683

____________________________________________________________

Burnout and Death Anxiety in Hospice Social Workers

Author: Quinn-Lee, Lisa; Olson-McBride, Leah; Unterberger, April

Publication info: Journal of Social Work in End-of-Life & Palliative Care  Vol. 10, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 219-239.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018766?accountid=14667

Abstract: Hospice work has been regarded as particularly stressful due to the complexity inherent in the provision of end-of-life care. Burnout and death anxiety are especially relevant to hospice social workers because they regularly function in a high-stress, high-loss environment. The purpose of this study was threefold: to determine the prevalence of burnout and death anxiety among hospice social workers; to examine associations between burnout and death anxiety; and to explore the factors which may contribute to the development of death anxiety and burnout. Participants completed four items: the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS), the Death Anxiety Questionnaire (DAQ), a demographic questionnaire, and a set of open-ended questions. Findings indicate that mean scores on the subscales of the MBI-HSS ranged from the low to moderate range and that a strong positive correlation existed between death anxiety and the depersonalization subscale of the MBI. Three key themes emerged from the qualitative data: (a) personal interest in hospice social work developed through a variety of ways; (b) although death anxiety decreased from exposure and understanding of the death process, there was increased death anxiety surrounding working with certain patients; and (c) burnout was primarily related to workload or difficult cases. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Burnout+and+Death+Anxiety+in+Hospice+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Quinn-Lee%2C+Lisa%3BOlson-McBride%2C+Leah%3BUnterberger%2C+April&amp;rft.aulast=Quinn-Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=219&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.issn=15524256&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15524256.2014.938891

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Burnout+and+Death+Anxiety+in+Hospice+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Quinn-Lee%2C+Lisa%3BOlson-McBride%2C+Leah%3BUnterberger%2C+April&amp;rft.aulast=Quinn-Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=219&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.issn=15524256&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15524256.2014.938891

Patterns of institutional change in minimum income protection in Sweden and Germany

Author: Angelin, Anna; Johansson, Hakan; Koch, Max

Publication info: Journal of International and Comparative Social Policy  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (January 2014): 165-179.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018775?accountid=14667

Abstract: Germany is generally regarded as a case of qualitative 'change' in minimum income protection (MIP) schemes, while Sweden is perceived as one of institutional 'inertia'. This paper seeks to qualify this view by embedding developments in MIP in wider policy and governance trends. Empirically, it is based on document analysis and qualitative expert interviews in the two countries. Theoretically, the paper applies recent institutional approaches that address patterns of change in more complex ways. In Sweden, an exclusive focus on formal continuity regarding social assistance would disguise its change in function from temporary security system of last resort into one that permanently provides income protection when neighboring policy fields, unemployment and sickness insurance, are downsized. Conversely, in Germany a merger of social assistance and unemployment assistance took place. Yet an exclusive focus on the Hartz reforms would downplay the degree of continuity that nevertheless exists in the unemployment insurance. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Patterns+of+institutional+change+in+minimum+income+protection+in+Sweden+and+Germany&amp;rft.au=Angelin%2C+Anna%3BJohansson%2C+Hakan%3BKoch%2C+Max&amp;rft.aulast=Angelin&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=165&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.937584

Protective Webs: Exploring a Role for School Social Workers on Behalf of Delinquent Youths

Author: Goldkind, Lauri

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 337-349.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018807?accountid=14667

Abstract: Annually, 100,000 delinquent youths return to their communities from a detention facility and are required to attend a community school. School social workers may be best positioned to provide assistance with this transition; however, little is understood about how they are presently servicing this population. This study explores the interactions of school social workers and the advocacy and assistance they provide on behalf of juvenile justice youths. The author surveyed a national sample of current school social workers (n = 4,279) and reports on their involvement with juvenile justice, their work on behalf of the youths' families as well as their interagency collaborations. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Protective+Webs%3A+Exploring+a+Role+for+School+Social+Workers+on+Behalf+of+Delinquent+Youths&amp;rft.au=Goldkind%2C+Lauri&amp;rft.aulast=Goldkind&amp;rft.aufirst=Lauri&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=337&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897103

The Current Status of Evidence-Based Practice in Juvenile Justice

Author: McKee, Esther Chao; Rapp, Lisa

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 308-317.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018846?accountid=14667

Abstract: The advent of evidence-based practice (EBP) has significantly changed the juvenile justice system while producing intense controversy. The intent of this article is to provide an update on the current status of EBP in the juvenile justice system. Specifically, this article will describe the evolution of juvenile justice philosophy as it has informed current juvenile justice policies and programs, discuss the scope of current juvenile justice research regarding EBP, identify barriers to implementing EBP, expound on the development of EBP in juvenile justice, discern the characteristics of evidence-based interventions in the juvenile justice system, and finally describe how to select and assess evidence-based practices and interventions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Current+Status+of+Evidence-Based+Practice+in+Juvenile+Justice&amp;rft.au=McKee%2C+Esther+Chao%3BRapp%2C+Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=McKee&amp;rft.aufirst=Esther&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=308&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897099

The Attitudes of Social Work Students Toward End-of-Life Care Planning

Author: Kwon, Sung Ae; Kolomer, Stacey; Alper, Jamie

Publication info: Journal of Social Work in End-of-Life & Palliative Care  Vol. 10, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 240-256.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018883?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the attitudes of social work students toward end-of-life care planning, as well as their degree of willingness to engage in this area of social work practice. Factors associated with their attitudes were measured through structured surveys completed by 102 social work students (N = 102) at a school of social work in the southeast. Results indicated that these social work students tended to have positive attitudes toward end-of-life care planning in general. Moreover, these attitudes were positively associated with preference for pain relief treatment, higher levels of comfort when discussing death, more emphasis on self-determination, and apprehension of conflicts of self-determination. The results of this study underscored the increased societal need for recognition of personal preferences in end-of-life care, higher levels of comfort when discussing death, and an increased commitment of social workers' to maintaining the ethical principle of the client's right to self-determination in end-of-life planning. While this is not surprising, it points to a continuing need to re-assess where the field stands in its preparation of social work professionals who will work closely with people who are dying and their families. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+Attitudes+of+Social+Work+Students+Toward+End-of-Life+Care+Planning&amp;rft.au=Kwon%2C+Sung+Ae%3BKolomer%2C+Stacey%3BAlper%2C+Jamie&amp;rft.aulast=Kwon&amp;rft.aufirst=Sung&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=240&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.issn=15524256&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15524256.2014.938890

Is Work-Family Enrichment an Antidote to Experiences of Psychological Strain Among Australian Social Workers? An Empirical Study

Author: Kalliath, Parveen

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 332-347.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018910?accountid=14667

Abstract: Few studies in work-family interface have explored the work-family experiences of social workers as an occupational group. Further, work-family conflict and its impact on psychological strain have dominated the majority of the literature. The positive effects of participation in work and family roles remain under-researched despite consensus among scholars confirming the benefits of participation in both roles. The present study contributes significantly to the gap in the literature by examining the work-family enrichment experiences of Australian social workers and its association with psychological strain. Data for the study were collected via online survey of the membership of the Australian Association of Social Workers and included one open-ended question asking social workers to comment on their work-family enrichment experiences. The survey yielded a usable sample of 439 responses. Hierarchical multiple regression analyses were conducted to examine the direct effects of the three forms of work-to-family enrichment (WFE) and family-to-work enrichment (FWE) on psychological strain. The results showed that WFE-Affect, WFE-Capital, and FWE-Affect were significantly associated with reduced psychological strain. The qualitative findings provided further evidence of the benefits associated with participation in work and family roles. The implications of the findings for theory, practice and service provision are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Work-Family+Enrichment+an+Antidote+to+Experiences+of+Psychological+Strain+Among+Australian+Social+Workers%3F+An+Empirical+Study&amp;rft.au=Kalliath%2C+Parveen&amp;rft.aulast=Kalliath&amp;rft.aufirst=Parveen&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.825302

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Is+Work-Family+Enrichment+an+Antidote+to+Experiences+of+Psychological+Strain+Among+Australian+Social+Workers%3F+An+Empirical+Study&amp;rft.au=Kalliath%2C+Parveen&amp;rft.aulast=Kalliath&amp;rft.aufirst=Parveen&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.825302

Active inclusion as an organisational challenge: integrated anti-poverty policies in three European countries

Author: Heidenreich, Martin; Petzold, Norbert; Natili, Marcello; Panican, Alexandru

Publication info: Journal of International and Comparative Social Policy  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (January 2014): 180-198.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018928?accountid=14667

Abstract: Active inclusion aims at the reduction of poverty by strengthening the agency of excluded persons by the provision of a minimum income, activation and social services. The contribution to poverty alleviation is determined by expenditure levels and the organisation of these three policy fields. This can be shown by three examples: The comprehensive Swedish regime is characterised by high expenditures; the redistributive German regime is characterised by lower service levels and in Italy, all three dimensions are least developed. In addition, the organisation of services differs: Decentralised and discretionary system for the provision of services in Sweden, 'creaming and parking' effects in Germany and fragmented providers in Italy. As a result of different expenditure levels and organisational patterns, the selectivity of active inclusion strategies is low in Sweden, medium in Germany and high in Italy. Both the financial and organisational dimensions of active inclusion therefore are decisive for poverty alleviation. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Active+inclusion+as+an+organisational+challenge%3A+integrated+anti-poverty+policies+in+three+European+countries&amp;rft.au=Heidenreich%2C+Martin%3BPetzold%2C+Norbert%3BNatili%2C+Marcello%3BPanican%2C+Alexandru&amp;rft.aulast=Heidenreich&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=180&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.934901

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Active+inclusion+as+an+organisational+challenge%3A+integrated+anti-poverty+policies+in+three+European+countries&amp;rft.au=Heidenreich%2C+Martin%3BPetzold%2C+Norbert%3BNatili%2C+Marcello%3BPanican%2C+Alexandru&amp;rft.aulast=Heidenreich&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=180&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2014.934901

Juvenile Reentry and Aftercare Interventions: Is Mentoring a Promising Direction?

Author: Abrams, Laura S; Mizel, Matthew L; Nguyen, Viet; Shlonsky, Aron

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 404-422.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018974?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study uses systematic review methods to investigate the use of mentoring programs to assist young people in successfully transitioning back into their communities following a juvenile correctional placement. Few studies were found that used comparison or control groups and measured recidivism outcomes. The results of the studies were mixed, with one study finding no differences between groups, and the other two studies finding some recidivism reductions among youth who received the intervention. However, the absence of detailed information on the interventions, weak research designs, and the diversity of the mentoring programs contributed to an overall dearth of knowledge about the effectiveness of these interventions in reducing recidivism. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Juvenile+Reentry+and+Aftercare+Interventions%3A+Is+Mentoring+a+Promising+Direction%3F&amp;rft.au=Abrams%2C+Laura+S%3BMizel%2C+Matthew+L%3BNguyen%2C+Viet%3BShlonsky%2C+Aron&amp;rft.aulast=Abrams&amp;rft.aufirst=Laura&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=404&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897115

Looking to the east and the west: the double-attachment strategy used by the Hong Kong government to develop welfare to work measures for lone parents

Author: Yu, Sam W.K.; Chau, Ruby C.M.; Boxall, Kathy; Chung, Wind C.Y.

Publication info: Journal of International and Comparative Social Policy  Vol. 30, Iss. 2,  (January 2014): 93-106.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019874?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses how the Hong Kong government used a double-attachment strategy to develop welfare to work measures for lone parents; and demonstrates how this discussion could contribute to the study of the cultural and political economy perspectives on East Asian welfare regimes. It shows that the Hong Kong government developed welfare to work measures with reference not only to the New Deal for Lone Parents in the UK, but also to certain traditional Chinese principles. In view of the Hong Kong government's attempt to attach its welfare policies to its own tradition and to the thinking of Western world, it is argued that both cultural and political economy perspectives are significant in the study of East Asian welfare regimes. Moreover, it is important to have a realistic understanding of the uniqueness of East Asian countries in the ways they organize welfare even though there are similarities with Western countries. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.atitle=Looking+to+the+east+and+the+west%3A+the+double-attachment+strategy+used+by+the+Hong+Kong+government+to+develop+welfare+to+work+measures+for+lone+parents&amp;rft.au=Yu%2C+Sam+W.K.%3BChau%2C+Ruby+C.M.%3BBoxall%2C+Kathy%3BChung%2C+Wind+C.Y.&amp;rft.aulast=Yu&amp;rft.aufirst=Sam&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+International+and+Comparative+Social+Policy&amp;rft.issn=21699763&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F21699763.2013.861357

Sexual Assault in Relationships: Seeking Help on a Q&A Website

Author: Webber, Ruth

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 363-376.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019980?accountid=14667

Abstract: Young people are increasingly turning to question-and-answer online environments such as Yahoo! Answers for advice. This paper reports on a qualitative investigation of the content and meaning behind 30 questions and 212 answers posted on Yahoo! Answers (2005-11) about incidents of sexual assault within a dating relationship or between school 'friends'. A comparison was made between the responses of sexual assault counsellors and other members. Interpretive description methodology was used in the analysis. Relationship status, time since the abuse, and age influenced the extent to which Askers were able to name the incident as abuse. The answers provided by counsellors typically included a supportive comment, advice (personal, legal, and medical), reflection or interpretation, resources, and places to go for help. Other members' answers lacked consistency, often failing to provide appropriate advice, empathy, and resources. Counselling organisations could consider providing online services for people who are seeking help for sexual assault. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sexual+Assault+in+Relationships%3A+Seeking+Help+on+a+Q%26amp%3BA+Website&amp;rft.au=Webber%2C+Ruth&amp;rft.aulast=Webber&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=363&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.834065

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sexual+Assault+in+Relationships%3A+Seeking+Help+on+a+Q%26amp%3BA+Website&amp;rft.au=Webber%2C+Ruth&amp;rft.aulast=Webber&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=363&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.834065

____________________________________________________________

The Parent Empowerment and Efficacy Measure (PEEM): A Tool for Strengthening the Accountability and Effectiveness of Family Support Services

Author: Freiberg, Kate; Homel, Ross; Branch, Sara

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 405-418.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019994?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the development, validity, and reliability of the Parent Empowerment and Efficacy Measure (PEEM). Development was guided by theory and by challenges faced by Pathways to Prevention family support staff who required a short, practical, and reliable measure of parent empowerment. The measure's psychometric properties were tested using data from 866 parents of children aged 5 to 12, living in high to low socioeconomic status areas. Principal factor analysis revealed a strong general dimension with high internal consistency (a = 0.92) that correlated at 0.60 or more with three validation measures, as well as the existence of two hypothesised subfactors (correlated at 0.78): efficacy to parent and efficacy to connect, each with internal consistencies of 0.85+. Test-retest reliability (n = 200) was 0.84. PEEM exhibits excellent convergent and concurrent validity and is a reliable tool for use in planning services, monitoring participant progress, and evaluating program effectiveness. Adapted from the source document.

Randomized Controlled Trials of Psychopharmacological Interventions of Children and Adolescents with Conduct Disorder: A Descriptive Analysis

Author: Sarteschi, Christine M

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 350-359.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019999?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study reviews and assesses published psychopharmaceutical randomized controlled trials targeting youths with the singular diagnosis of conduct disorder. Computerized database searches were completed to identify all randomized controlled trials. Fifteen studies were located and reviewed. Of the 15 studies, none were longer than 10 weeks in length, and none had more than 100 participants. The majority were conducted in inpatient hospital settings, with all-male participants. Methodological quality reporting of trials was poor and inconsistent. Findings indicate that there is a need to plan and implement future, lengthy conduct disorder medication trials that follow the Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials guidelines. The relevance for social work practice and policy is discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Randomized+Controlled+Trials+of+Psychopharmacological+Interventions+of+Children+and+Adolescents+with+Conduct+Disorder%3A+A+Descriptive+Analysis&amp;rft.au=Sarteschi%2C+Christine+M&amp;rft.aulast=Sarteschi&amp;rft.aufirst=Christine&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=350&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897105

Creating the Final Conversations Scale: A Measure of End-of-Life Relational Communication with Terminally Ill Individuals

Author: Generous, Mark Alan; Keeley, Maureen P

Publication info: Journal of Social Work in End-of-Life & Palliative Care  Vol. 10, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 257-281.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020001?accountid=14667

Abstract: Final conversations (FCs) are defined as the communicative interactions, both verbal and nonverbal, that occur between terminally ill patients and relational partners. In this study, the 'Final Conversations Scale' was developed and tested. A total of 152 participants that had engaged in final conversations with individuals that were terminally ill completed the newly developed instrument. Factor analysis produced a five-factor structure, including: messages of spirituality/religion; expressions of love; proactive difficult relationship talk; everyday communication; and talk about illness/death. Participants' perceptions of the relational closeness and difficulty with the deceased significantly influenced the individuals' recalled frequency of FCs messages. Practical and scholarly implications focus on the needs of the family members regarding their communication with terminally ill individuals, as well as directions for future research with the FCs Scale. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Creating+the+Final+Conversations+Scale%3A+A+Measure+of+End-of-Life+Relational+Communication+with+Terminally+Ill+Individuals&amp;rft.au=Generous%2C+Mark+Alan%3BKeeley%2C+Maureen+P&amp;rft.aulast=Generous&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.issn=15524256&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15524256.2014.938892

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Creating+the+Final+Conversations+Scale%3A+A+Measure+of+End-of-Life+Relational+Communication+with+Terminally+Ill+Individuals&amp;rft.au=Generous%2C+Mark+Alan%3BKeeley%2C+Maureen+P&amp;rft.aulast=Generous&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+in+End-of-Life+%26+Palliative+Care&amp;rft.issn=15524256&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15524256.2014.938892

Looking Back and Thinking Forward: Examining the Consequences of Policies and Practices That Treat Juveniles as Adults

Author: Shook, Jeffrey J

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 392-403.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020040?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the consequences of legislative changes that eased the process of treating juveniles as adults. Overall, it finds evidence that there has been an increase in the number of juveniles sent to the criminal court and the majority either remain in the community or return to the community shortly after serving a jail or prison sentence. In light of geographic and racial/ethnic disparities in transfer, differences in the programs and services offered to youth in the juvenile and criminal justice systems, and higher rates of recidivism among transferred offenders, the article supports the contention of many scholars and advocates that there is a need for policy and practice reform. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Looking+Back+and+Thinking+Forward%3A+Examining+the+Consequences+of+Policies+and+Practices+That+Treat+Juveniles+as+Adults&amp;rft.au=Shook%2C+Jeffrey+J&amp;rft.aulast=Shook&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeffrey&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=392&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897112

Gender Differences in Juvenile Gang Members: An Exploratory Study

Author: Hayward, R Anna; Honegger, Laura

Publication info: Journal of Evidence-Based Social Work  Vol. 11, Iss. 4,  (January 2014): 373-382.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020049?accountid=14667

Abstract: Over the past two decades, gang membership within the United States has continued to rise and has spread from urban centers to suburban and rural areas. Juvenile gang membership is of particular concern because of the relationship between early gang involvement and later adolescent and adult criminal behavior and incarceration. Female gang membership and affiliation are receiving increased attention as female crime and incarceration rates outpace those of their male counterparts. This study explores gender differences between male and female juveniles who have verified gang membership in one suburban jurisdiction. Findings suggest important differences between males and females, and implications for research and practice are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+Differences+in+Juvenile+Gang+Members%3A+An+Exploratory+Study&amp;rft.au=Hayward%2C+R+Anna%3BHonegger%2C+Laura&amp;rft.aulast=Hayward&amp;rft.aufirst=R&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=373&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Evidence-Based+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15433714&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.897110

Improving Outcomes for Unemployed and Homeless Young People: Findings of the YP4 Clinical Controlled Trial of Joined Up Case Management

Author: Grace, Marty; Gill, Peter Richard

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 419-437.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020087?accountid=14667

Abstract: The YP4 study was a clinical controlled trial (CCT) of joined up services for young people experiencing both homelessness and unemployment in Victoria, Australia. The joined up service delivery (J group, n = 222) participants were offered intensive client-centred case management, involving direct provision of a range of services as well as the brokering of additional services. The standard services (S group, n = 174) participants remained eligible for standard services. Access to the Australian Government income support agency's (Centrelink) administrative data provided a retention rate close to 90% over the three annual data collection points of the study (baseline, 12 months and 24 months). Both groups improved their circumstances over the two years of the trial. The results showed no statistically significant treatment effects. The effect for employment earnings was approaching significance (p = .06) with J group increasing their employment earnings to a greater extent than S group. The findings and their implications for the implementation of joined up case management, future policy and practice, and future homelessness research is discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Improving+Outcomes+for+Unemployed+and+Homeless+Young+People%3A+Findings+of+the+YP4+Clinical+Controlled+Trial+of+Joined+Up+Case+Management&amp;rft.au=Grace%2C+Marty%3BGill%2C+Peter+Richard&amp;rft.aulast=Grace&amp;rft.aufirst=Marty&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=419&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2014.911926

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Improving+Outcomes+for+Unemployed+and+Homeless+Young+People%3A+Findings+of+the+YP4+Clinical+Controlled+Trial+of+Joined+Up+Case+Management&amp;rft.au=Grace%2C+Marty%3BGill%2C+Peter+Richard&amp;rft.aulast=Grace&amp;rft.aufirst=Marty&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=419&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2014.911926

Subject: Homelessness; Case Management; Australia; Employment; Youth; Trials; Policy Implementation; Methodology (Data Collection); Attrition

____________________________________________________________

Social Work's Role in Prenatal Diagnosis and Genetic Services: Current Practice and Future Potential

Author: Azri, Stephanie; Larmar, Stephen; Cartmel, Jennifer

Publication info: Australian Social Work  Vol. 67, Iss. 3,  (January 2014): 348-362.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660020114?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although the development of sophisticated technologies associated with prenatal testing processes have assisted in the practice of prenatal diagnosis, limited attention has been given to the complexities surrounding the decision-making processes for pregnant women following a poor or fatal diagnosis. An emerging international body of knowledge suggests that the process of having prenatal testing and then deciding on whether to continue a wanted pregnancy is often difficult and traumatic. In the last 50 years, social workers have played an invaluable role in the provision of holistic counselling and support for children and families in a range of areas and contexts. This paper highlights the unique contributions that social workers can bring to the field of prenatal testing. It emphasises the consideration of strengths and values inherent within social work practice that provides appropriate and timely support for women who have received a poor or fatal diagnosis following prenatal testing. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work%27s+Role+in+Prenatal+Diagnosis+and+Genetic+Services%3A+Current+Practice+and+Future+Potential&amp;rft.au=Azri%2C+Stephanie%3BLarmar%2C+Stephen%3BCartmel%2C+Jennifer&amp;rft.aulast=Azri&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=67&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=348&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Australian+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=0312407X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0312407X.2013.848914

Defining Signature Pedagogy in Social Work Education: Learning Theory and the Learning Contract

Author: Boitel, Craig R; Fromm, Laurentine R

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 608.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947265?accountid=14667

Abstract: In 2008, the Council on Social Work Education identified field education as the signature pedagogy of social work. In doing so, it designated field education as the synthetic, integrative curricular area in which students are socialized to the profession. This article examines challenges and opportunities this designation presents. How field education can be designed and delivered as social work education's signature pedagogy is discussed from a learning theory framework. A learning contract is described that integrates class and field in attainment of the core and advanced competencies. Use of this integrated learning contract by the field instructor and student serves to structure the field experience in a manner consistent with a signature pedagogy. The teaching role of the field instructor is recognized as a key component of the signature pedagogy. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Defining+Signature+Pedagogy+in+Social+Work+Education%3A+Learning+Theory+and+the+Learning+Contract&amp;rft.au=Boitel%2C+Craig+R%3BFromm%2C+Laurentine+R&amp;rft.aulast=Boitel&amp;rft.aufirst=Craig&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=608&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Defining+Signature+Pedagogy+in+Social+Work+Education%3A+Learning+Theory+and+the+Learning+Contract&amp;rft.au=Boitel%2C+Craig+R%3BFromm%2C+Laurentine+R&amp;rft.aulast=Boitel&amp;rft.aufirst=Craig&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=608&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Perceived Levels of Cultural Competence for School Social Workers: A Follow-Up Study

Author: Teasley, Martell L; Archuleta, Adrian; Miller, Christina

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 694.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947282?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to report on findings from a follow-up study that examined the relationship among social work education programs, postgraduate professional development, and school social workers' perceived levels of cultural competence in practice with an urban minority youth. The initial study demonstrated that African Americans perceived a higher level of cultural competence than their Anglo American counterparts did. Findings highlight the need to understand the processes by which practitioners become culturally competent for urban school social work practice. Underscoring the importance of professional development, the authors determined that geographic location of practice may serve as a factor that influences how practitioners anticipate the need for culturally competent practice with diverse populations. Implications for practice and future research are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Perceived+Levels+of+Cultural+Competence+for+School+Social+Workers%3A+A+Follow-Up+Study&amp;rft.au=Teasley%2C+Martell+L%3BArchuleta%2C+Adrian%3BMiller%2C+Christina&amp;rft.aulast=Teasley&amp;rft.aufirst=Martell&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=694&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Teaching Note-Integrating Prevention Content Into Clinical Social Work Practice Courses

Author: Rishel, Carrie W

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 752.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947348?accountid=14667

Abstract: Rapid changes in health care services and delivery suggest an upcoming paradigm shift in the field of mental health. Recent national reports, health care policy changes, and growing evidence support a shift toward prevention-focused mental health care. The social work profession is uniquely positioned to act as leaders in this shift as the profession's values, goals, and hallmark practice approach are consistent with preventive care. Most social work students, however, do not receive training in prevention practice. The author's development, implementation, and evaluation of a prevention-focused master of social work elective in the area of mental health is presented as an example of integrating prevention content into clinical social work practice courses. Implications for social work education are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+Note-Integrating+Prevention+Content+Into+Clinical+Social+Work+Practice+Courses&amp;rft.au=Rishel%2C+Carrie+W&amp;rft.aulast=Rishel&amp;rft.aufirst=Carrie&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=752&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A Campus-Community Partnership to Disseminate Health Internet Technology Resources Among African Americans

Author: Littlefield, Melissa B; Edwards, Lorece; Akers, Timothy

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 648.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947385?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Internet is increasingly used to disseminate health information about diseases and prevention and to help in obtaining health services. Although technology can empower African Americans to adopt healthy lifestyles, the gap in usage between African Americans and Whites undermines the potential power of health Internet technology (IT) to ameliorate health disparities. This study describes the development, implementation, and outcome of health informatics intervention by a university-community partnership to increase awareness and use of health IT resources among African Americans to address the problem of their underuse of online health resources. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=A+Campus-Community+Partnership+to+Disseminate+Health+Internet+Technology+Resources+Among+African+Americans&amp;rft.au=Littlefield%2C+Melissa+B%3BEdwards%2C+Lorece%3BAkers%2C+Timothy&amp;rft.aulast=Littlefield&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=648&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work Values in Human Services Administration: Implications for Social Work Education

Author: Watson, Larry D; Hoefer, Richard

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 623.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947481?accountid=14667

Abstract: The perceived wisdom in the social work education community, based on an empirical research from the 1990s and the early part of this century, says that the master of social work (MSW) degree is not competitive with the master of business administration or the master of public administration to obtain top-level administration jobs in nonprofit agencies. This article reviews recent information on hiring preferences of board chairs that provides new hope that the MSW degree with a concentration in management or administration is perceived as a viable and useful degree for top-level positions in human services agencies. Thus, current board chairs are more inclined to value the MSW than administrators and academics from years past. The reason is that the values of social workers are seen as quite valuable in the current environment. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Values+in+Human+Services+Administration%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Watson%2C+Larry+D%3BHoefer%2C+Richard&amp;rft.aulast=Watson&amp;rft.aufirst=Larry&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=623&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Teaching Note-Heterosexism as Experienced by LGBT Social Work Educators

Author: Johnson, Lisa M

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 748.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947499?accountid=14667

Abstract: As social work educators, much of our practice involves helping students think critically about complex political, economic, and social issues. One of the most complex and contentious sociopolitical issues of our time has been civil rights for lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) persons. This teaching note considers how we, as LGBT instructors, may respond to students' comments about LGBT-related issues when such comments are representative of ideas that challenge our personal identities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+Note-Heterosexism+as+Experienced+by+LGBT+Social+Work+Educators&amp;rft.au=Johnson%2C+Lisa+M&amp;rft.aulast=Johnson&amp;rft.aufirst=Lisa&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=748&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Change and Deeper Change: Transforming Social Work Education

Author: Witkin, Stanley L

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education  Vol. 50, Iss. 4,  (0, 2014): 587.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1667947702?accountid=14667

Abstract: In recent years, the concept of transformation has become more prevalent in the social work literature; however, its use is quite varied. In this article, the author attempts to disentangle some of these uses. He then propose a conceptualization of transformation and discuss its relevance for social work education. In this conceptualization, transformation is considered an orientation to learning and knowing rather than about particular content or an end state. He concludes with some ideas about how this conceptualization might be integrated into social work education. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Change+and+Deeper+Change%3A+Transforming+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Witkin%2C+Stanley+L&amp;rft.aulast=Witkin&amp;rft.aufirst=Stanley&amp;rft.date=2014-01-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=587&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
