Exploring the Ethical Dilemma of Integrating Social Work Values and Military Social Work Practice

Author: Olson, Mark Douglas

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 183-185.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541995552?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers often encounter situations in which they are required to function in systems where competing philosophies coexist. One example is the divergent philosophies of social work and the military. Throughout its history, social work has advocated peace as an essential means to achieving social and economic justice. At the same time, professional social workers have been an integral part of the military system dating back to World War I, when social workers joined forces with the Red Cross to treat victims of 'shell shock' (Council on Social Work Education [CSWE], 2010). Currently, the Veterans Administration is the nations' largest employer of professional social workers and provider of graduate internships (NASW, 2012). Defining an ethical dilemma as 'a predicament in which the decision-maker must choose between two options of near or equal value,' Tallant and Ryberg (2000) posited that military social workers may be forced to choose between the military mission and their client. This dilemma exemplifies the paradox of the social worker within the military system. In recent years, CSWE has called for enhancing content on military practice in social work curricula. Although cautioning that it is not endorsing 'war or aggression,' CSWE has argued that increasing students' capacity to work with veterans will establish social workers as leaders in military care and secure future employment opportunities (CSWE, 2010). However, discrepancies between the culture and philosophy of the military system and the social work profession warrant further discussion. The juxtaposition between the profession's advocacy for peace and the call for greater military content in social work education presents an ethical dilemma regarding how these disparate positions can be reconciled within social work pedagogy. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+Ethical+Dilemma+of+Integrating+Social+Work+Values+and+Military+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Olson%2C+Mark+Douglas&amp;rft.aulast=Olson&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=183&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu010

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+Ethical+Dilemma+of+Integrating+Social+Work+Values+and+Military+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Olson%2C+Mark+Douglas&amp;rft.aulast=Olson&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=183&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu010

Economic Insecurity and Access to the Social Safety Net among Latino Farmworker Families

Author: Padilla, Yolanda C1; Scott, Jennifer L; Lopez, Olivia1 School of Social Work, University of Texas at Austin, 1925 San Jacinto Boulevard, Austin, TX 78712 ypadilla@utexas.edu

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 157-165.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996089?accountid=14667

Abstract: Farmworkers experience pervasive economic insecurity in part because of the seasonal nature of agricultural work and limited employment protections. Yet little is known about the adequacy of the social safety net in responding to farmworker needs. Using data from the 2005-2009 National Agricultural Workers Survey (N = 10,469), the current study analyzed predictors of social welfare participation among Latinos, who represent approximately 80 percent of all farmworkers. Nearly 95 percent are immigrants, although almost half of them have lived in the United States for more than 10 years. Descriptive analyses showed that, even among farmworker households whose income fell below the poverty line or that were headed by legally documented individuals, social services use was very low. Logistic regression analyses revealed that degree of social integration influenced social welfare participation, controlling for education, poverty status, family composition, and employment characteristics. Latino farmworkers who were recent immigrants (that is, in the United States for less than five years) had significantly lower odds of access to social insurance and public assistance programs relative to their U.S.-born counterparts. Low self-reported English ability significantly decreased access to most social insurance programs but not public assistance receipt. The findings indicate the need for social workers to engage in outreach efforts and policy advocacy to improve farmworkers access to social welfare. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Economic+Insecurity+and+Access+to+the+Social+Safety+Net+among+Latino+Farmworker+Families&amp;rft.au=Padilla%2C+Yolanda+C%3BScott%2C+Jennifer+L%3BLopez%2C+Olivia&amp;rft.aulast=Padilla&amp;rft.aufirst=Yolanda&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu013

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Economic+Insecurity+and+Access+to+the+Social+Safety+Net+among+Latino+Farmworker+Families&amp;rft.au=Padilla%2C+Yolanda+C%3BScott%2C+Jennifer+L%3BLopez%2C+Olivia&amp;rft.aulast=Padilla&amp;rft.aufirst=Yolanda&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu013

Indigenous Social Workers' Turnover Intentions in Taiwan: We Are More Disadvantaged than Our Clients!

Author: Chong, Hiu Ha11 Department of Indigenous Development and Social Work, National Dong Hwa University, No. 1, Sec. 2, Da Hsueh Rd, Shoufeng, Hualien 97401, Taiwan, ROC hhchong@mail.ndhu.edu.tw

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 559-577.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996130?accountid=14667

Abstract: After an observation of the high turnover rate among Indigenous social workers, particularly working in small Indigenous-owned local community associations in eastern Taiwan, research was conducted to understand the dynamic issues activating turnover intention. Twelve Indigenous service providers from six organisations underwent semi-structure interviews. The findings revealed that workers from small agencies are less protected whilst undertaking an entire range of problems and crises transferred from different tiers of organisations compared to their counterparts from larger organisations. An in-depth analysis demonstrated that Indigenous social work is increasingly dominated by a neo-liberal phenomenon, thereby imposing a strong threat to both the bidding organisations and the workers and creating adverse working conditions. Power further exerts itself in particular ways via the interaction between workers and organisations, activating turnover intentions. The findings urge a greater awareness of sensitivity to the heterogeneity of Indigenous communities, and encourage rethinking the strategies to improve employee retention and labour conditions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Indigenous+Social+Workers%27+Turnover+Intentions+in+Taiwan%3A+We+Are+More+Disadvantaged+than+Our+Clients%21&amp;rft.au=Chong%2C+Hiu+Ha&amp;rft.aulast=Chong&amp;rft.aufirst=Hiu&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=559&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs143

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Indigenous+Social+Workers%27+Turnover+Intentions+in+Taiwan%3A+We+Are+More+Disadvantaged+than+Our+Clients%21&amp;rft.au=Chong%2C+Hiu+Ha&amp;rft.aulast=Chong&amp;rft.aufirst=Hiu&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=559&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs143

Subject: Indigenous Populations; Workers; Social Workers; Taiwan; Attrition; Threat; Communities; Work Environment; Neoliberalism

Communities Respond to Predatory Lending

Author: Caplan, Mary Ager

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 149-156.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996336?accountid=14667

Abstract: Low-income communities in the United States have faced a history of financial marginalization and exploitation, most evident today in the proliferation of predatory financial services, such as payday lending and check-cashing services. Ameliorating the negative effects of predatory lending has become increasingly important on the agenda of community development efforts and the field of social work. Through the use of case studies, this article describes three specific strategies that communities use to increase financial inclusion and buffer against the deleterious effects of predatory lending: inclusion, community-based alternatives, and community advocacy. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Communities+Respond+to+Predatory+Lending&amp;rft.au=Caplan%2C+Mary+Ager&amp;rft.aulast=Caplan&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu008

The Best of Times, the Worst of Times: Social Work and Its Moment

Author: Jones, Ray11 Professor of Social Work, Kenry House, Kingston University, Kingston Hill Campus, Kingston upon Thames, Surrey, KT2 7LB, UK r.l.jones@sgul.kingston.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 485-502.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996354?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work in the UK has had a torrid time, castigated for not protecting children from risk and cornered as the rationer of scarce resources for adults. Over the past sixty years, it has struggled to create a strong and appropriate professional space and its identity and role have remained contested. This paper recounts the debates and dilemmas which have encompassed and engrossed social work, but also recognises that there is now a stronger platform in the UK for social work as a profession. The paper notes what is special about social work and how it might be promoted. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Best+of+Times%2C+the+Worst+of+Times%3A+Social+Work+and+Its+Moment&amp;rft.au=Jones%2C+Ray&amp;rft.aulast=Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=Ray&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=485&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs157

Re-Enchanting Social Work? The Emerging 'Spirit' of Social Work in an Age of Economic Crisis

Author: Garrett, Paul Michael11 Senior Lecturer, National University of Ireland, School of Political Science and Sociology, Galway, Republic of Ireland PM.Garrett@nuigalway.ie

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 503-521.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541996982?accountid=14667

Abstract: Luc Boltanski and Eve Chiapello's (2005) The New Spirit of Capitalism argues that capitalism has the capacity to absorb critique and become ideologically energised and discursively reinvigorated on account of this capacity. This article argues that their theorisation provides a useful theoretical lens through which to view and comprehend present attempts to re-enchant the profession and discursively infuse it with a new 'spirit', in times of 'austerity' and budget cuts: hence, the emerging emphasis on social work as a 'creative' profession needing to free itself from 'bureaucracy'. Although partly heeding the critique derived from the academic literature illuminating the constraints imposed on social work by an ever-expanding digital e-workload, this move is deeply ideological and needs to be warily regarded. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Re-Enchanting+Social+Work%3F+The+Emerging+%27Spirit%27+of+Social+Work+in+an+Age+of+Economic+Crisis&amp;rft.au=Garrett%2C+Paul+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Garrett&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=503&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs146

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Re-Enchanting+Social+Work%3F+The+Emerging+%27Spirit%27+of+Social+Work+in+an+Age+of+Economic+Crisis&amp;rft.au=Garrett%2C+Paul+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Garrett&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=503&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs146

Male Victims of Intimate Partner Abuse: Use and Helpfulness of Services

Author: Tsui, Venus

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 121-130.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541997539?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data obtained from a national study of male victims or survivors of intimate partner abuse (IPA) indicate that the experience (current or past) of abuse and with service use may predict a positive perception toward help seeking. However, marital status and a tendency to minimize problems may predict negative attitudes toward help seeking. Empirical evidence from this mixed-method study suggests that male victims face many interpersonal and societal obstacles. Feeling uncomfortable when requesting assistance, men in IPA situations are affected by a masking factor that causes them to hide their situation and contributes to a misconception factor that causes people to treat men as the sole perpetrator. Although men are eligible, services may not be perceived as being available or helpful. The study yields important implications for social work practice, and the findings result in several recommendations for increased awareness about IPA, advocacy for gender-inclusive services, revision of laws and policies, increased research, and emphasis on funded and anonymous services. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Male+Victims+of+Intimate+Partner+Abuse%3A+Use+and+Helpfulness+of+Services&amp;rft.au=Tsui%2C+Venus&amp;rft.aulast=Tsui&amp;rft.aufirst=Venus&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu007

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Male+Victims+of+Intimate+Partner+Abuse%3A+Use+and+Helpfulness+of+Services&amp;rft.au=Tsui%2C+Venus&amp;rft.aulast=Tsui&amp;rft.aufirst=Venus&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=121&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu007

Building Resilient Practitioners: Definitions and Practitioner Understandings

Author: Adamson, Carole1; Beddoe, Liz; Davys, Allyson1 School of Counselling, Human Services and Social Work, Faculty of Education, University of Auckland, Private Bag, 92-601 Symonds St, Auckland, New Zealand c.adamson@auckland.ac.nz

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 522-541.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541997574?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper turns the conceptual focus of resilience from that of the service user and community to the experience of social workers themselves. It reports on aspects of an ongoing study into social work practitioner resilience in health care and non-statutory practice settings in New Zealand. This continuing study explores the perceptions of experienced social workers in relation to resilience in the face of workplace demands and stressors. After clarifying common definitional challenges regarding the conceptualisation of resilience in the literature, qualitative data from twenty-one interviews are examined and a conceptual framework is proposed which identifies three components of resilience: core attributes, practice context and mediating factors. The narratives of the participants suggest a multi-faceted and dynamically-balanced awareness of resilience that emphasises the relational and contextual characteristics of their experience. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Building+Resilient+Practitioners%3A+Definitions+and+Practitioner+Understandings&amp;rft.au=Adamson%2C+Carole%3BBeddoe%2C+Liz%3BDavys%2C+Allyson&amp;rft.aulast=Adamson&amp;rft.aufirst=Carole&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=522&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs142

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Building+Resilient+Practitioners%3A+Definitions+and+Practitioner+Understandings&amp;rft.au=Adamson%2C+Carole%3BBeddoe%2C+Liz%3BDavys%2C+Allyson&amp;rft.aulast=Adamson&amp;rft.aufirst=Carole&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=522&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs142

Social Work and Collegiate Recovery Programs

Author: Steiker, Lori K Holleran1; Grahovac, Ivana; White, William L1 School of Social Work, University of Texas at Austin, Room 3.122A, 1925 San Jacinto Boulevard, Austin, TX 78712-1203

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 177-180.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541999709?accountid=14667

Abstract: Collegiate recovery programs (CRPs) are networks of services and fellowship-oriented groups designed to meet the support needs of college students in or in need of recovery, the CRP model is growing exponentially, and many CRPs include staffed centers. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Do Organisational Culture and Climate Really Matter for Employee Turnover in Child Welfare Agencies?

Author: Shim, MiSeung11 Department of Public Administration, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, Republic of Korea msshim@chonnam.ac.kr

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 542-558.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541999855?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to investigate the effects of organisational culture and climate on employee turnover at public child welfare agencies. The data are drawn from public child welfare agencies in New York State. The empirical analysis indicates (i) that low-turnover agencies have more positive or constructive organisational culture and climate than high-turnover agencies; (ii) that, in particular, emphasis on rewards among organisational culture subscales and reduction in workload among organisational climate subscales show significant differences between two groups of agencies; and (iii) that only emphasis on rewards among organisational culture subscales has a significant and negative effect, or reduction, on employee turnover rates. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Do+Organisational+Culture+and+Climate+Really+Matter+for+Employee+Turnover+in+Child+Welfare+Agencies%3F&amp;rft.au=Shim%2C+MiSeung&amp;rft.aulast=Shim&amp;rft.aufirst=MiSeung&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=542&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs162

Signs of Sociolinguistic Misunderstanding: The Case of a Boy Named HUNTER

Author: Nonaka, Angela M

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 59, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 187-190.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1541999890?accountid=14667

Abstract: When dealing with linguistically diverse clients, social work professionals know they must be ready to bridge communicative gaps, but sometimes more is required, and it is necessary to be a language advocate. At an early learning center in Nebraska in 2012, a controversy erupted that required informed language advocacy. Hunter Spanjer (his name in English) was then a deaf preschool student who was learning a system of manually coded English called Signing Exact English (SEE). His name sign in SEE is HUNTER. This name sign became a source of contention between Hunter's parents and school officials. The Spanjer family said that the school 'told them the manner in which the boy signs his name is a violation of its 'weapons in school' policy' and therefore that 'Hunter had to modify the way he signs his moniker to comply with the school's zero tolerance code against weapons in school' ('Nebraska Family, School at Odds over Deaf Boy's 'Gun-Like' Sign Language Name,' 2012). 'A school spokesman called the issue a 'misunderstanding' and said that it had nothing to do with guns or weapons' (Caulfield, 2012). Public response to the story was strongly sympathetic to the family, resulting in 'hundreds of angry calls and emails, even death threats' (Eiten, 2012). Understanding this incident is important for school social workers, who easily could have landed in the middle of the dispute, being asked to mediate or advocate for either the student or the school. Three major sociolinguistic misapprehensions underlie this episode involving differences between (1) SEE and American Sign Language (ASL), (2) names and naming practices in the hearing versus deaf communities in the United States, and (3) signed language versus gesture and misperceptions about communicative aggression. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Signs+of+Sociolinguistic+Misunderstanding%3A+The+Case+of+a+Boy+Named+HUNTER&amp;rft.au=Nonaka%2C+Angela+M&amp;rft.aulast=Nonaka&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu009

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Signs+of+Sociolinguistic+Misunderstanding%3A+The+Case+of+a+Boy+Named+HUNTER&amp;rft.au=Nonaka%2C+Angela+M&amp;rft.aulast=Nonaka&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=59&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu009

A National Comparative Study over One Decade of Children with Intellectual Disabilities Living Away from Their Natural Parents

Author: McConkey, Roy1; Kelly, Fionnola; Craig, Sarah1 Institute of Nursing Research, University of Ulster, Newtownabbey, BT37 0QB, Northern Ireland, UK r.mcconkey@ulster.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 714-728.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000612?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children with intellectual disabilities are more likely than non-disabled children to live away from their families. Internationally, the aspiration is for them to live at home or in alternative family placements. This study uses national data on over 700 children from the Republic of Ireland to monitor their living arrangements over a ten-year period. In that time, the numbers of children in care had fallen significantly and especially for those in residential settings aged ten years and over. Nonetheless, proportionately more children with intellectual disability of all ages moved away from their families, especially those aged ten to nineteen years. However, compared to non-disabled children, fewer were placed in foster-care, although the extent of this varied across the local health areas. Over the ten-year period, only small proportions of children returned to their families or moved from residential to foster-care. These findings are combined with those from international studies to identify changes in service provision and social work. A particular challenge is the promotion of cross-sector working between mainstream child and family services with specialist disability services. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+National+Comparative+Study+over+One+Decade+of+Children+with+Intellectual+Disabilities+Living+Away+from+Their+Natural+Parents&amp;rft.au=McConkey%2C+Roy%3BKelly%2C+Fionnola%3BCraig%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=McConkey&amp;rft.aufirst=Roy&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=714&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs170

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+National+Comparative+Study+over+One+Decade+of+Children+with+Intellectual+Disabilities+Living+Away+from+Their+Natural+Parents&amp;rft.au=McConkey%2C+Roy%3BKelly%2C+Fionnola%3BCraig%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=McConkey&amp;rft.aufirst=Roy&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=714&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs170

Young People with Complex Needs: Designing Coordinated Interventions to Promote Resilience across Child Welfare, Juvenile Corrections, Mental Health and Education Services

Author: Ungar, Michael1; Liebenberg, Linda; Ikeda, Janice1 Correspondence to Michael Ungar, Ph.D., PO Box 15000, 6420 Coburg Road, Halifax, B3H 4R2, Canada. : www.michaelungar.com

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 675-693.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000787?accountid=14667

Abstract: Young people with complex needs (YPCNs) use multiple services that are often poorly coordinated despite the best efforts of social workers to act as case managers. Based on two case studies from research with 116 youth who are multiple service users in Atlantic Canada, six principles for the design of services are suggested reflecting both this study's findings and the broader literature on YPCNs. Services that are (i) multi-level, (ii) coordinated, (iii) continuous over time, (iv) negotiated with users, (v) provided along a continuum from least to most intrusive and (vi) shown to be effective are more likely to meet the long-term needs of youth facing the cumulative disadvantages of family, community, school and individual challenges. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Young+People+with+Complex+Needs%3A+Designing+Coordinated+Interventions+to+Promote+Resilience+across+Child+Welfare%2C+Juvenile+Corrections%2C+Mental+Health+and+Education+Services&amp;rft.au=Ungar%2C+Michael%3BLiebenberg%2C+Linda%3BIkeda%2C+Janice&amp;rft.aulast=Ungar&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=675&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs147

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Young+People+with+Complex+Needs%3A+Designing+Coordinated+Interventions+to+Promote+Resilience+across+Child+Welfare%2C+Juvenile+Corrections%2C+Mental+Health+and+Education+Services&amp;rft.au=Ungar%2C+Michael%3BLiebenberg%2C+Linda%3BIkeda%2C+Janice&amp;rft.aulast=Ungar&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=675&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs147

A National Disability Insurance Scheme: What Social Work Has to Offer

Author: Fawcett, Barbara1; Plath, Debbie1 University of Sydney-Faculty of Education and Social Work, Camperdown Campus Sydney, Sydney, New South Wales, NSW 2006, Australia

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 747-762.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000960?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper appraises key features of the recently proposed National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) in Australia and explores underpinning conceptualisations of 'disability', 'autonomy', 'choice' and 'assessment'. In particular, it examines the ways in which the Scheme reconfigures a continuation of individualised payments and care package policies. These proposals can be seen to have international significance in terms of how new policy is formulated and also implemented in this controversial field. It is argued that, by utilising embedded human rights perspectives, social work practice principles and social model understandings of disability, social workers can play a crucial role in reframing the opportunities presented by key policy changes. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+National+Disability+Insurance+Scheme%3A+What+Social+Work+Has+to+Offer&amp;rft.au=Fawcett%2C+Barbara%3BPlath%2C+Debbie&amp;rft.aulast=Fawcett&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=747&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs141

Prevalence of Adverse Childhood Experiences in a University Population: Associations with Use of Social Services

Author: McGavock, Lian1; Spratt, Trevor1 Queen's University Belfast, School of Sociology, Social Policy and Social Work, 6 College Park, Belfast, BT7 1NN, Northern Ireland

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 657-674.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000963?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is part of a series published by the Multiple Adverse Childhood Experiences research group based at Queen's University Belfast. First-year undergraduates took part in an online survey, self-reporting on Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACE) and measures of social service contact. The ten-item ACE questionnaire measures abuse, neglect and household dysfunction (current sample a = 0.711). The study achieved a response rate of 18.6 per cent (N = 765; 552 (72.7 per cent) females and 212 (27.2 per cent) males, 21.8 per cent reporting having been educated at a 'Protestant' school, 42 per cent reporting having been educated at a 'Catholic' school and 20.4 per cent reporting previous school religious affiliation as 'other'). Despite obvious non-response bias, ACE scores for this student population are comparable with college-educated populations in the USA. Current respondents with previous social service contact are over twenty-three times more likely than peers to have experienced multiple adversities. Findings support the hypothesis that social service contact, alone, acts as a proxy indicator for the presence of multiple adverse childhood experiences, with no significant elevation in ACE scores for those going through court proceedings or subject to child protection registration. This study supports current concerns by policy makers to target those children experiencing multiple adversities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Prevalence+of+Adverse+Childhood+Experiences+in+a+University+Population%3A+Associations+with+Use+of+Social+Services&amp;rft.au=McGavock%2C+Lian%3BSpratt%2C+Trevor&amp;rft.aulast=McGavock&amp;rft.aufirst=Lian&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=657&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs127

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Prevalence+of+Adverse+Childhood+Experiences+in+a+University+Population%3A+Associations+with+Use+of+Social+Services&amp;rft.au=McGavock%2C+Lian%3BSpratt%2C+Trevor&amp;rft.aulast=McGavock&amp;rft.aufirst=Lian&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=657&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs127

Exploring the Contribution of Self-Assessment to Preventative Services in Social Care

Author: Abendstern, Michele1; Hughes, Jane; Clarkson, Paul; Tucker, Sue; Challis, David1 University of Manchester, Personal Social Services Research Unit, Manchester, Greater Manchester, UK michele.abendstern@manchester.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 44, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 729-746.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1542000997?accountid=14667

Abstract: Prevention, comprising services that seek to delay deterioration of existing conditions and circumstances or prevent their occurrence by early access to support, is recognised as having an important role in adult social care. The gateway to social care services has traditionally been via needs-led assessments undertaken with professionals. In England, self-assessment, promoted as a means of accessing services more independently, has come to the fore in recent years. This article explores the relationship between prevention and self-assessment in practice. Data are derived from interviews with social services managers of five self-assessment projects situated within the adult social care sector that were described as providing a preventative approach, as well as project development documentation. A number of issues are highlighted including for whom self-assessment might be most optimal, the potential of self-assessment to widen access and the role it can play in promoting self-determination. It is argued that a natural relationship exists between self-assessment and prevention and that both concepts are at the core of the personalisation agenda. However, in order to achieve its potential in practice, self-assessment must be offered in conjunction with support and as an additional rather than alternative means of accessing preventative services. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+Contribution+of+Self-Assessment+to+Preventative+Services+in+Social+Care&amp;rft.au=Abendstern%2C+Michele%3BHughes%2C+Jane%3BClarkson%2C+Paul%3BTucker%2C+Sue%3BChallis%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Abendstern&amp;rft.aufirst=Michele&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=44&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=729&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcs144

'It Gets Better' ... but How? Exploring Resilience Development in the Accounts of LGBTQ Adults

Author: Asakura, Kenta1; Craig, Shelley L1 Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 253-266.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996586?accountid=14667

Abstract: As reports of bullying and suicide increase, research on lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) youth must expand its focus from vulnerabilities to resilience development. The purpose of this inductive qualitative study was to explore resilience development in the accounts of LGBTQ adults by analyzing videos posted for the It Gets Better social media campaign (n = 21). Four major themes emerged: (1) leaving hostile social environments; (2) experiencing 'coming out' in meaningful ways; (3) remembering the social environment; and (4) turning challenges into opportunities and strengths. These findings suggest that, despite the campaign's premise, life did not automatically get better for the LGBTQ participants. Rather, the findings offer a nuanced look at the pathways to resilience development. Implications for social work practice are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=%27It+Gets+Better%27+...+but+How%3F+Exploring+Resilience+Development+in+the+Accounts+of+LGBTQ+Adults&amp;rft.au=Asakura%2C+Kenta%3BCraig%2C+Shelley+L&amp;rft.aulast=Asakura&amp;rft.aufirst=Kenta&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=253&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.808971

Hospital to Community Transitions for Adults: Discharge Planners and Community Service Providers' Perspectives

Author: Chapin, Rosemary Kennedy1; Chandran, Devyani; Sergeant, Julie F; Koenig, Terry L1 Office of Aging and Long Term Care, School of Social Welfare, University of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care  Vol. 53, Iss. 4,  (April 2014): 311-329.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996603?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discharges from the hospital to community-based settings are more difficult for older adults when there is lack of communication, resource sharing, and viable partnerships among service providers in these settings. The researchers captured the perspectives of three different groups of participants from hospitals, independent living centers, and Area Agencies on Aging, which has rarely been done in studies on discharge planning. Findings include identification of barriers in the assessment and referral process (e.g., timing of discharge, inattention to client goals, lack of communication and partnerships between hospital discharge planners and community providers), and strategies for overcoming these barriers. Implications are discussed including potential for Medicaid and Medicare cost reductions due to fewer re-hospitalizations. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Hospital+to+Community+Transitions+for+Adults%3A+Discharge+Planners+and+Community+Service+Providers%27+Perspectives&amp;rft.au=Chapin%2C+Rosemary+Kennedy%3BChandran%2C+Devyani%3BSergeant%2C+Julie+F%3BKoenig%2C+Terry+L&amp;rft.aulast=Chapin&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosemary&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=53&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=311&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2014.884037

The Critical Role of Social Workers in Home-Based Primary Care

Author: Reckrey, Jennifer M1; Gettenberg, Gabrielle; Ross, Helena; Kopke, Victoria; Soriano, Theresa; Ornstein, Katherine1 Icahn School of Medicine, Mount Sinai, New York, New York, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care  Vol. 53, Iss. 4,  (April 2014): 330-343.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996669?accountid=14667

Abstract: The growing homebound population has many complex biomedical and psychosocial needs and requires a team-based approach to care (Smith, Ornstein, Soriano, Muller, & Boal, 2006). The Mount Sinai Visiting Doctors Program (MSVD), a large interdisciplinary home-based primary care program in New York City, has a vibrant social work program that is integrated into the routine care of homebound patients. We describe the assessment process used by MSVD social workers, highlight examples of successful social work care, and discuss why social workers' individualized care plans are essential for keeping patients with chronic illness living safely in the community. Despite barriers to widespread implementation, such social work involvement within similar home-based clinical programs is essential in the interdisciplinary care of our most needy patients. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=The+Critical+Role+of+Social+Workers+in+Home-Based+Primary+Care&amp;rft.au=Reckrey%2C+Jennifer+M%3BGettenberg%2C+Gabrielle%3BRoss%2C+Helena%3BKopke%2C+Victoria%3BSoriano%2C+Theresa%3BOrnstein%2C+Katherine&amp;rft.aulast=Reckrey&amp;rft.aufirst=Jennifer&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=53&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=330&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2014.884041

Interdisciplinary Team Communication Among Forensic Nurses and Rape Victim Advocates

Author: Patterson, Debra11 School of Social Work, Wayne State University, Detroit, Michigan, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care  Vol. 53, Iss. 4,  (April 2014): 382-397.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996673?accountid=14667

Abstract: Victim advocates and forensic nurses provide integrated care to address the complex legal, medical, and mental health needs of rape survivors. Research suggests that conflict exists between nurses and advocates, but it remains unknown how their communication patterns contribute to or resolve these conflicts. Utilizing a qualitative case study approach, the current study interviewed 24 nurses and advocates from a Midwest organization to better understand team communication patterns when addressing conflicts. The findings suggest that most nurses communicate concerns directly while advocates avoid direct communication. Factors that influenced direct and indirect communication and their implications for practice will be discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Factors Associated With Diabetes-Related Distress: Implications for Diabetes Self-Management

Author: Wardian, Jana1; Sun, Fei1 Southwest Interdisciplinary Research Center, Arizona State University, Phoenix, Arizona, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Health Care  Vol. 53, Iss. 4,  (April 2014): 364-381.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996674?accountid=14667

Abstract: As 7.8% of the U.S. population is affected by diabetes, health care providers are tasked with providing resources to assist patients toward self-management. Psychosocial issues have an effect on diabetes self-care. Diabetes-related distress is associated with self-management and lower A1C. This cross-sectional study seeks to understand how demographic factors, psychological orientations, support, and diabetes management behaviors predict diabetes-related distress. This study uses data from 267 adults with Type 2 diabetes. The Diabetes Distress Scale (DDS) is a 17-item scale measuring diabetes-related distress including emotional distress, physician-related distress, regimen distress, and interpersonal distress. Hierarchical regression was conducted in four stages. The final model explains 48% of the variance in DDS. Significant factors related to lower DDS were older age, lower body mass index, higher self-efficacy, higher levels of health care provider support, and a healthy diet. Findings of this study help health care providers know where to focus to reduce diabetes-related distress. Health care provider support is significant in reducing DDS. Diabetes education may want to include strategies that increase self-efficacy and assist people with diabetes to obtain a healthy weight through a more healthful diet. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+With+Diabetes-Related+Distress%3A+Implications+for+Diabetes+Self-Management&amp;rft.au=Wardian%2C+Jana%3BSun%2C+Fei&amp;rft.aulast=Wardian&amp;rft.aufirst=Jana&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=53&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=364&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2014.884038

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+With+Diabetes-Related+Distress%3A+Implications+for+Diabetes+Self-Management&amp;rft.au=Wardian%2C+Jana%3BSun%2C+Fei&amp;rft.aulast=Wardian&amp;rft.aufirst=Jana&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=53&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=364&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.issn=00981389&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00981389.2014.884038

____________________________________________________________

Flourishing among Japanese Immigrants: A Positive Approach to Understanding Psychosocial Adaptation

Author: Ando, Sachi11 Center for Social Work Education, Widener University, Chester, Pennsylvania, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 301-315.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996685?accountid=14667

Abstract: Immigration can be an opportunity-maximizing and resource-creating process for immigrants. This cross-sectional survey study examined flourishing, the optimal state of psychosocial adaptation, in relation to social capital and acculturation, among a sample of 380 Japanese immigrants who lived in Texas. The study revealed that well-acculturated Japanese immigrants who enjoy U.S. culture and traditions as well as have more online and face-to-face contacts were more likely to have higher levels of flourishing. The findings have practical implications for social work practice in terms of the use of immigrants' social capital to enhance their acculturation process and enable them to flourish. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Flourishing+among+Japanese+Immigrants%3A+A+Positive+Approach+to+Understanding+Psychosocial+Adaptation&amp;rft.au=Ando%2C+Sachi&amp;rft.aulast=Ando&amp;rft.aufirst=Sachi&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=301&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.831008

What Are the Ideal Characteristics of Empirically Supported Treatment Adopters?

Author: Patterson Silver Wolf (Adelv unegv Waya), David A.11 George Warren Brown School of Social Work, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 408-414.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996795?accountid=14667

Abstract: There has been a clear and consistent shift in social work practice from offering treatment as usual to implementing empirically supported treatments (ESTs). As social work researchers and practitioners continue to evaluate the effectiveness of ESTs, their impact on clinical outcomes, and the various obstacles to their adoption, a developing literature could offer some guidance on characteristics of EST adopters. This article provides a beginning discussion of the ideal characteristics of EST adopters both at the organizational and individual levels. While this is a developing area of study, there are some important findings that could better serve community-based organizations, their work force, and the communities they serve. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=What+Are+the+Ideal+Characteristics+of+Empirically+Supported+Treatment+Adopters%3F&amp;rft.au=Patterson+Silver+Wolf+%28Adelv+unegv+Waya%29%2C+David+A.&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson+Silver+Wolf+%28Adelv+unegv+Waya%29&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=408&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.875343

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=What+Are+the+Ideal+Characteristics+of+Empirically+Supported+Treatment+Adopters%3F&amp;rft.au=Patterson+Silver+Wolf+%28Adelv+unegv+Waya%29%2C+David+A.&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson+Silver+Wolf+%28Adelv+unegv+Waya%29&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=408&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.875343

The L'Arche Program for Persons with Disabilities

Author: Thulberry, Sarah C1; Thyer, Bruce A1 College of Social Work, Florida State University, Tallahassee, Florida, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 348-357.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996819?accountid=14667

Abstract: The International Federation of L'Arche is made up of intentional, ecumenical, faith-based communities where people with and without developmental disabilities live together. Data on the worldwide federation offers an understanding of L'Arche communities that celebrate and encourage diversity and solidarity. Characteristics of clients and assistants as well as the daily running of homes reveal the inner workings of the program. Through assessing strengths and weaknesses, it is shown that even though L'Arche is a small movement that cannot serve every person with a developmental disability by providing a home and a place of belonging, this program offers a program model with many strengths that should be replicated. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=The+L%27Arche+Program+for+Persons+with+Disabilities&amp;rft.au=Thulberry%2C+Sarah+C%3BThyer%2C+Bruce+A&amp;rft.aulast=Thulberry&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=348&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.831012

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=The+L%27Arche+Program+for+Persons+with+Disabilities&amp;rft.au=Thulberry%2C+Sarah+C%3BThyer%2C+Bruce+A&amp;rft.aulast=Thulberry&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=348&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.831012

Correlates of Race and Substance Abuse with Religious Support Systems: A Study of Pregnant Substance Abusers

Author: Pilkinton, Melinda W11 Social Work Program, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, Mississippi, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 390-398.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996914?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women who misuse substances may have decreased connections with community structures, including religious support systems. This study examined the correlates of race, age, socioeconomic status, and drug use status on 1,116 pregnant women's connections with religious support structures. Data were derived from the 2002 National Survey of Drug Abuse and the 2003 National Survey of Drug Use and Health and were used to perform a secondary analysis of the variables. Results of the analyses revealed that race is not an indicator of social connectivity; while drug use, age, and socioeconomic status are indicators. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Correlates+of+Race+and+Substance+Abuse+with+Religious+Support+Systems%3A+A+Study+of+Pregnant+Substance+Abusers&amp;rft.au=Pilkinton%2C+Melinda+W&amp;rft.aulast=Pilkinton&amp;rft.aufirst=Melinda&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=390&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.875336

Hospice and Self-Assessed Quality of Life in the Dying: A Review

Author: Prost, Stephanie Grace11 College of Social Work, Florida State University, Tallahassee, Florida, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 281-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550996929?accountid=14667

Abstract: This review summarizes the impact of hospice and palliative end-of-life care on the self-assessed quality of life (QoL) in terminally ill persons. Articles were included if researchers utilized at least two observations post-hospice admission and were published in English between January of 2000 and December 2012. Findings from included studies synthesize results of a variety of terminal patients (n = 1,017) across settings. Only one study utilized a non-treatment control group. The remaining studies compared variations of program inclusions, settings, or QoL scores across carcinoma site. The studies included indicated mixed outcomes related to the effect of hospice on QoL in the dying. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Hospice+and+Self-Assessed+Quality+of+Life+in+the+Dying%3A+A+Review&amp;rft.au=Prost%2C+Stephanie+Grace&amp;rft.aulast=Prost&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=281&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.820159

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Hospice+and+Self-Assessed+Quality+of+Life+in+the+Dying%3A+A+Review&amp;rft.au=Prost%2C+Stephanie+Grace&amp;rft.aulast=Prost&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=281&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.820159

Alcohol Screening and Brief Intervention as Standard Practice: Working with the American Indian/Native Alaskan Populations

Author: Patterson Silver Wolf (Adelv unegv Waya), David A.1; Duran, Bonnie; Dulmus, Catherine N; Manning, Amy R1 George Warren Brown School of Social Work, Washington University in St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 399-407.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550997501?accountid=14667

Abstract: Alcohol use and the resulting problems associated with high-risk drinking in the American Indian/Native Alaskan (AI/NA) population are well-documented, as alcohol misuse has taken an incredible toll on many AI/NA communities. Presently, both overall health issues and alcohol use occur disproportionately within this population. This article provides an updated overview of the impact of alcohol use in the United States and within AI/NA communities specifically. It also provides recommendations for an alcohol-related screening and brief intervention instrument that social workers can begin using in their practice and can be utilized within the AI/NA community. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Alcohol+Screening+and+Brief+Intervention+as+Standard+Practice%3A+Working+with+the+American+Indian%2FNative+Alaskan+Populations&amp;rft.au=Patterson+Silver+Wolf+%28Adelv+unegv+Waya%29%2C+David+A.%3BDuran%2C+Bonnie%3BDulmus%2C+Catherine+N%3BManning%2C+Amy+R&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson+Silver+Wolf+%28Adelv+unegv+Waya%29&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=399&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2014.875340

____________________________________________________________

Examining Cohort Differences and Resilience among the Aging LGBT Community: Implications for Education and Practice among an Expansively Diverse Population

Author: Dentato, Michael P1; Orwat, John; Spira, Marcia; Walker, Benjamin1 School of Social Work, Loyola University, Chicago, Illinois, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 316-328.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550997561?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aging lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) community continues to grow considerably while often being faced with unique and unmet needs separate from younger LGBT cohorts or their non-LGBT counterparts. This article explores some of the differences in attitudes among generational cohort groups regarding coming out decisions; sexual risk and safety; the impact of evolving policies within systems and society; as well as the demonstrated strengths and resiliencies of the aging LGBT community. Implications and suggestions for education, training, and best practices among this expansive and diverse population are considered as well as continued research in the field of LGBT aging. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Examining+Cohort+Differences+and+Resilience+among+the+Aging+LGBT+Community%3A+Implications+for+Education+and+Practice+among+an+Expansively+Diverse+Population&amp;rft.au=Dentato%2C+Michael+P%3BOrwat%2C+John%3BSpira%2C+Marcia%3BWalker%2C+Benjamin&amp;rft.aulast=Dentato&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=316&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.831009

Mexican American and European American Adolescents' Dating Experiences across the Ecosystem: Implications for Healthy Relationships within an Ecodevelopmental Framework

Author: Rueda, Heidi Adams1; Nagoshi, Julie L; Williams, Lela Rankin1 Social Work Department, University of Texas at San Antonio, San Antonio, Texas, USA

Publication info: Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (April 2014): 358-376.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1550997585?accountid=14667

Abstract: Dating health interventions that target the complex, multi-systemic spheres in which adolescents experience their first romantic relationships are required. This study utilizes an ecodevelopmental approach to better understand Mexican American and European American youths' perceptions of how peers, parents, school, and the media act both independently and collectively to affect their dating lives, also elucidating how such systems are at times in conflict. Seventy-five middle adolescents participated in focus groups divided by gender and ethnicity to uncover differences and similarities within and across groups. Findings underscore the importance and widespread effects of romantic relationships for adolescents' social development and the need for intervention programs that target multiple points of intervention while attending to meso systemic conflicts across systems. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Mexican+American+and+European+American+Adolescents%27+Dating+Experiences+across+the+Ecosystem%3A+Implications+for+Healthy+Relationships+within+an+Ecodevelopmental+Framework&amp;rft.au=Rueda%2C+Heidi+Adams%3BNagoshi%2C+Julie+L%3BWilliams%2C+Lela+Rankin&amp;rft.aulast=Rueda&amp;rft.aufirst=Heidi&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=358&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.831013

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.atitle=Mexican+American+and+European+American+Adolescents%27+Dating+Experiences+across+the+Ecosystem%3A+Implications+for+Healthy+Relationships+within+an+Ecodevelopmental+Framework&amp;rft.au=Rueda%2C+Heidi+Adams%3BNagoshi%2C+Julie+L%3BWilliams%2C+Lela+Rankin&amp;rft.aulast=Rueda&amp;rft.aufirst=Heidi&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=358&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Human+Behavior+in+the+Social+Environment&amp;rft.issn=10911359&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10911359.2013.831013

Explaining the perceived justice of disaster relief policy: An empirical study based on the 2008 Wenchuan Earthquake in China

Author: Zhang, Huan11 School of Social Development & Public Policy, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 150-164.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1559003877?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Chinese government issued generous relief policies after the Wenchuan Earthquake. However, according to my survey, 20.32 per cent (n = 1,949) of the earthquake victim-survivors felt that they were treated unfairly in receiving government assistance after the earthquake. In the present study, a perceived justice framework was established to explain the victim-survivors' perception of justice of the disaster relief policy in China and several hypotheses were developed. The hypotheses were tested empirically using household survey data of the Wenchuan Earthquake. The empirical study found that perceived justice, which is composed of three dimensions (distributive justice, interpersonal justice and informational justice), could directly assess the effect of the disaster relief policy. The results of the empirical study also demonstrated that the most important principle of the disaster relief policy was 'need distribution', which was also the most important factor of perceived justice. The study concluded that it is imperative to improve victim-survivors' feeling of fairness, policy information delivery and their expectations management when implementing a disaster relief policy. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Explaining+the+perceived+justice+of+disaster+relief+policy%3A+An+empirical+study+based+on+the+2008+Wenchuan+Earthquake+in+China&amp;rft.au=Zhang%2C+Huan&amp;rft.aulast=Zhang&amp;rft.aufirst=Huan&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=150&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12050

The ideological roots of the support for welfare state reform: Support for distributive and commodifying reform in The Netherlands

Author: Achterberg, Peter1; Veen, Romke; Raven, Judith1 Department of Sociology, Faculty of Social Sciences, Erasmus University, Rotterdam, The Netherlands

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 215-226.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1559004653?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the extent to which four major trends in welfare state reform -- privatisation, increasing selectivity, increasing activation and increasing discipline -- are supported and how this support can be explained. Using recent public opinion data of the Dutch population, it is found that there are two ideological dimensions underlying welfare reform support, the first tapping distributive reform, the latter tapping commodifying reform. While support for distributive reform in the direction of decreasing redistribution can solely be explained by economic interests and economic values, support for commodifying reform can also be explained culturally. It appears that one's cultural position and cultural ideological values are important for support for commodifying reform. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+ideological+roots+of+the+support+for+welfare+state+reform%3A+Support+for+distributive+and+commodifying+reform+in+The+Netherlands&amp;rft.au=Achterberg%2C+Peter%3BVeen%2C+Romke%3BRaven%2C+Judith&amp;rft.aulast=Achterberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=215&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12043

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+ideological+roots+of+the+support+for+welfare+state+reform%3A+Support+for+distributive+and+commodifying+reform+in+The+Netherlands&amp;rft.au=Achterberg%2C+Peter%3BVeen%2C+Romke%3BRaven%2C+Judith&amp;rft.aulast=Achterberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Peter&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=215&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12043

Economic openness and welfare state attitudes: A multilevel study across 67 countries

Author: Koster, Ferry11 Faculty of Social Sciences, Department of Sociology, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Rotterdam, The Netherlands

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 128-138.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1559004689?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article extends previous studies investigating economic globalisation and the welfare state by examining individual attitudes, ranging from a preference for individual responsibility (economic individualism) to public demand for government intervention (social equality), across a large number of countries. It formulates different hypotheses about the direct and moderating effects of economic openness on these attitudes. The multilevel analysis, investigating data from 99,663 citizens of 67 countries, leads to the following two conclusions. First, economic openness is associated with a stronger preference for economic individualism and less demand for government intervention. Second, groups benefiting from globalisation and right-wing voters have a stronger preference for economic individualism if the economic openness of their country is higher. Key Practitioner Message: The results show that some vulnerable groups demand more social protection in economically more open countries. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Economic+openness+and+welfare+state+attitudes%3A+A+multilevel+study+across+67+countries&amp;rft.au=Koster%2C+Ferry&amp;rft.aulast=Koster&amp;rft.aufirst=Ferry&amp;rft.date=2014-04-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=128&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12040

A critical review of mental health and mental health-related policies in China: More actions required

Author: Wong, Daniel Fu Keung1; Zhuang, Xiao Yu; Pan, Jia-Yan; He, Xue Song1 Department of Applied Social Studies, City University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 2,  (April 2014): 195-204.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1559004690?accountid=14667

Abstract: In China, there are over 170 million people suffering from mental illness. However, there is a lack of a critical review of the policies governing the provision of mental health services. Drawing on the framework of mental health policy developed by the WHO, this article critically examines mental health policies regarding legislation, financing, model of care and delivery, as well as manpower and the training of mental health professionals in China. This analysis raises a number of policy-related questions concerning the lack of community-based psychiatric services, inadequate coverage of mental health services in the rural areas, poor standard of education and an insufficient number of trained mental health professionals, and insufficient protection of the human rights of people with mental illness. The article ends by urging the various levels of governments to make a firm commitment to improve mental health care for people with mental illness in China. Adapted from the source document.
