FIELDWORK EDUCATION IN HEALTH CONTEXTS: EXPERIENCES OF FOURTH-YEAR BSW STUDENTS

Author: Beytell, Anna-Marie

Publication info: Maatskaplike Werk/Social Work  Vol. 50, Iss. 2,  (June 2014): 170-192.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672344?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social work profession faces many challenges in practice and these have an influence on the fieldwork education of students. Social work organisations are challenged with a lack of material and human resources, but the demands in terms of service rendering increase as a consequence of major social concerns, for example, poverty, physical and sexual abuse, violence and disease, and this is occurring in complex contexts where cultural sensitivity is a necessity. Legislative changes in other professions such as medicine and teaching, as well as the attention of the media, contribute to higher expectations from social workers. Fulcher (2008:66) regards some of these demands as 'unrealistic and a burden for the profession.' This tendency exists not only in South Africa, but globally. Globerman and Bogo (2002:7) focus on changes in healthcare in Canada, where social workers face increasingly complex volumes of cases along with staff reductions and less time to work with patients because the length of hospital stays is decreasing. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.atitle=FIELDWORK+EDUCATION+IN+HEALTH+CONTEXTS%3A+EXPERIENCES+OF+FOURTH-YEAR+BSW+STUDENTS&amp;rft.au=Beytell%2C+Anna-Marie&amp;rft.aulast=Beytell&amp;rft.aufirst=Anna-Marie&amp;rft.date=2014-06-01&amp;rft.volume=50&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=170&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Maatskaplike+Werk%2FSocial+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378054&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

VALIDATING THE EVIDENCE OF VIOLENCE IN PARTNER RELATIONSHIPS WITH REGARD TO XHOSA AFRICAN WOMEN

Author: Mesatywa, Nontando Jennifer

Publication info: Maatskaplike Werk/Social Work  Vol. 50, Iss. 2,  (June 2014): 235-255.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672347?accountid=14667

Abstract: Gender-based violence is increasingly attracting national and international recognition as an issue of human rights abuse. This is the reason why Millennium Goal No. 3 is envisaged in the world of gender equity, equality and fairness in the treatment of women. Although domestic violence seems to be a widespread phenomenon in South Africa, not much has been documented about the perceptions and experiences of African women in violent partner relationships. Much information is based on eclectic data sources, whilst reliable statistics on African women in abusive relationships are inadequate, unavailable or scarce. However, results obtained in a study covering three provinces - the Eastern Cape, Mpumalanga and Limpopo - confirmed the widely held belief that partner violence against women is a major problem in South Africa (Jewkes, Penn-Kekana, Levin, Ratsaka & Schrieber, 1999:20). Adapted from the source document.

Ableism and economic rationalism in Australian immigration

Author: Yu, Nilan G

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2014): 254-261.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1539381773?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is an analysis of the current immigration policy in Australia from the perspective of critical social work. The analysis is based on the outcomes of the immigration applications of three families of children with disabilities. It is argued that, as seen in the experience of the three families, Australian immigration policy is markedly underpinned by ableism and economic rationalism, rendering the assessment process to determine immigration eligibility patently discriminatory against people with disabilities and their families. Such discriminatory practice is seen as a challenge for social work practice. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Ableism+and+economic+rationalism+in+Australian+immigration&amp;rft.au=Yu%2C+Nilan+G&amp;rft.aulast=Yu&amp;rft.aufirst=Nilan&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=254&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12058

The social dimensions of happiness and life satisfaction of Australians: Evidence from the World Values Survey

Author: Vinson, Tony; Ericson, Matthew

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2014): 240-253.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1539381775?accountid=14667

Abstract: Relatively short-term verbal therapies and other forms of intervention may help people to overcome difficult passages in life, but studies in recent decades have pointed to the salience of social and economic conditions in shaping life satisfaction and happiness. The present study contributes to our knowledge of this field by extending the range of social factors considered, but also, crucially, by the employment of statistical analyses that serve to disentangle the often overlapping variables associated with life satisfaction and happiness. Our results support previous 'demographic' findings as well as new results including education, marriage, children, human rights and, particularly in the context of Australian society, perceived choice in life. Establishing what the major contributing factors are can assist the formulation of social policy. Moreover, it can alert practitioners to the value of consolidating their work by encouraging service users to utilise community sources that enhance life satisfaction and/or happiness. Key Practitioner Message: -- The informed linking of service users to sources of life satisfaction and happiness can 'value add' direct service interventions; -- The salience of exercising individual choice to achieving life satisfaction reinforces the importance of the practice principle of self-determination; -- A person's sense of physical wellbeing is a relevant part of social assessment and subsequent planned actions. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+social+dimensions+of+happiness+and+life+satisfaction+of+Australians%3A+Evidence+from+the+World+Values+Survey&amp;rft.au=Vinson%2C+Tony%3BEricson%2C+Matthew&amp;rft.aulast=Vinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Tony&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=240&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12062

Increasing conflict in times of retrenchment? Attitudes towards healthcare provision in Europe between 1996 and 2002

Author: Naumann, Elias

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2014): 276-286.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1539381776?accountid=14667

Abstract: Public opinion is considered a major obstacle to changing the status quo of welfare state policies. Yet some far-reaching reforms and gradual changes of European welfare states prompt the reverse question: Have increased reform pressures and restructuring efforts led to changes in individual attitudes? In line with previous research, I found that the strong support for a public provision of healthcare remains unchanged. But what about the structure of attitudes? Testing core assumptions of the new politics theory and power resources theory, I looked at conflict lines within society and how they change in times of retrenchment. Analysing individual attitudes in 14 European countries between 1996 and 2002, I moved beyond static comparisons across countries to provide a dynamic account of trends over time. Observing stability, not change, I found no evidence that the relevance of old cleavages is in decline. Both old and new cleavages shape individual attitudes. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Increasing+conflict+in+times+of+retrenchment%3F+Attitudes+towards+healthcare+provision+in+Europe+between+1996+and+2002&amp;rft.au=Naumann%2C+Elias&amp;rft.aulast=Naumann&amp;rft.aufirst=Elias&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=276&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12067

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Increasing+conflict+in+times+of+retrenchment%3F+Attitudes+towards+healthcare+provision+in+Europe+between+1996+and+2002&amp;rft.au=Naumann%2C+Elias&amp;rft.aulast=Naumann&amp;rft.aufirst=Elias&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=276&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12067

____________________________________________________________

Value orientations of social welfare policy structures

Author: Garlington, Sarah B

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2014): 287-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1539381783?accountid=14667

Abstract: Substantial literature exists around the variation of welfare policy development in liberal democracies. The contrast of the American welfare state to those in Europe has sparked significant analytical literature about which factors are most significant in the variation. The literature extensively examines many of these factors but has neglected the significance of social values. This article discusses values and policy development as a foundation for further studies linking specific values to policy and institutional development. First, I discuss theorists who have identified value orientation as significant to welfare state variation; second, I review the major comparative welfare state literature. Finally, I discuss the major variation categories through the lens of social values by identifying the significant value orientation of sample policy structures. Comparative welfare state literature benefits from elucidating the values orientation of welfare policies that define the welfare state typological categories. Including the role of social values in welfare state comparisons promotes greater understanding of the origins and trajectory of current policy. Key Practitioner Message: -- Increase understanding of welfare state variation factors; -- Frame questions about social values reflected in social policy. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Value+orientations+of+social+welfare+policy+structures&amp;rft.au=Garlington%2C+Sarah+B&amp;rft.aulast=Garlington&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=287&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12056

Social assistance in Shanghai: Dynamics between social protection and informal employment

Author: Wong, Yu-Cheung; Chen, Honglin; Zeng, Qun

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2014): 333-341.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1539381791?accountid=14667

Abstract: China's social assistance programme (dibao ä½Zä¿oe) was introduced in Shanghai in 1993 and gradually extended to cover all urban areas by 1998. Due to massive economic restructuring, starting in the early 1990s, many urban dibao recipients were laid-off, that is, state-owned enterprise (SOE) employees. Shanghai was the epicentre of SOE reform, and the dibao system was primarily introduced to provide a safety net for laid-off workers. In 2010, approximately 3 per cent of urban, permanent residents were on dibao, and 72 per cent of its recipients were working-age adults. We conducted longitudinal qualitative interviews five times over 2 years with 40 dibao families that contained adults of working age in a Shanghai district. The current study demonstrates how they managed their employment, income and the dibao system. Findings suggested that, for various reasons, there was insufficient motivation for recipients to gain reemployment and leave dibao. Furthermore, local cadres, which were responsible for assessing and recommending dibao applicants to the district government, likely just assumed the incomes of adults with working capabilities. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Social+assistance+in+Shanghai%3A+Dynamics+between+social+protection+and+informal+employment&amp;rft.au=Wong%2C+Yu-Cheung%3BChen%2C+Honglin%3BZeng%2C+Qun&amp;rft.aulast=Wong&amp;rft.aufirst=Yu-Cheung&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=333&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12048

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Social+assistance+in+Shanghai%3A+Dynamics+between+social+protection+and+informal+employment&amp;rft.au=Wong%2C+Yu-Cheung%3BChen%2C+Honglin%3BZeng%2C+Qun&amp;rft.aulast=Wong&amp;rft.aufirst=Yu-Cheung&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=333&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12048

Income redistribution in 20 countries over time

Author: Wang, Chen; Caminada, Koen; Goudswaard, Kees

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2014): 262-275.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1539381794?accountid=14667

Abstract: In most OECD countries, the gap between rich and poor has widened over the past decades. The present study analysed whether and to what extent direct taxes and social transfers contribute to this trend. The study contributes to the literature by disentangling several parts of fiscal redistribution in a comparative setting. We used micro-data from the Luxembourg Income Study to examine household market inequality and redistribution from transfers and taxes for 20 countries from the mid-1980s to the mid-2000s. The contribution of each programme was estimated using a sequential accounting budget incidence decomposition technique. We observed a sizeable increase in primary household inequality, but tax-benefit systems have offset two thirds of the average increase in primary income inequality. The public old-age pensions attributed 60 per cent to the increase in redistribution, while social assistance accounted for 20 per cent. Direct taxes slowed down redistribution by 16 per cent. [PUBLICATION ABSTRACT]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Income+redistribution+in+20+countries+over+time&amp;rft.au=Wang%2C+Chen%3BCaminada%2C+Koen%3BGoudswaard%2C+Kees&amp;rft.aulast=Wang&amp;rft.aufirst=Chen&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=262&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12061

ADOPTING EVIDENCE-BASED MEDICALLY ASSISTED TREATMENTS IN SUBSTANCE ABUSE TREATMENT ORGANIZATIONS: ROLES OF LEADERSHIP SOCIALIZATION AND FUNDING STREAMS

Author: Blum, Terry C; Davis, Carolyn D; Roman, Paul M

Publication info: Journal of Health and Human Services Administration  Vol. 37, Iss. 1,  (July 2014): 37-75.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1629329884?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper examines the organizational adoption of medically assisted treatments (MAT) for substance use disorders (SUDs) in a representative sample of 555 US for-profit and not-for-profit treatment centers. The study examines organizational adoption of these treatments in an institutionally contested environment that traditionally has valued behavioral treatment, using sociological and resource dependence frameworks The findings indicate that socialization of leadership, measured by formal clinical education, is related to the adoption of MAT. Funding patterns also affect innovation adoption, with greater adoption associated with higher proportions of earned income from third party fees for services, and less adoption associated with funding from criminal justice sources. These findings may generalize to other social mission-oriented organizations where innovation adoption may be linked to private and public benefit values inherent in the type of socialization of leadership and different patterns of funding support. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=ADOPTING+EVIDENCE-BASED+MEDICALLY+ASSISTED+TREATMENTS+IN+SUBSTANCE+ABUSE+TREATMENT+ORGANIZATIONS%3A+ROLES+OF+LEADERSHIP+SOCIALIZATION+AND+FUNDING+STREAMS&amp;rft.au=Blum%2C+Terry+C%3BDavis%2C+Carolyn+D%3BRoman%2C+Paul+M&amp;rft.aulast=Blum&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.issn=10793739&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=ADOPTING+EVIDENCE-BASED+MEDICALLY+ASSISTED+TREATMENTS+IN+SUBSTANCE+ABUSE+TREATMENT+ORGANIZATIONS%3A+ROLES+OF+LEADERSHIP+SOCIALIZATION+AND+FUNDING+STREAMS&amp;rft.au=Blum%2C+Terry+C%3BDavis%2C+Carolyn+D%3BRoman%2C+Paul+M&amp;rft.aulast=Blum&amp;rft.aufirst=Terry&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.issn=10793739&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY OF NONPROFIT SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCIES

Author: Paynter, Sharon; Berner, Marueen

Publication info: Journal of Health and Human Services Administration  Vol. 37, Iss. 1,  (July 2014): 111-145.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1629329975?accountid=14667

Abstract: The U.S. social safety net is formed by governmental and nonprofit organizations, which are trying to respond to record levels of need. This is especially true for local level organizations, such as food pantries. The organizational capacity literature has not covered frontline, local, mostly volunteer and low resource organizations in the same depth as larger ones. This analysis is a consideration of whether grassroots nonprofit organizations have the ability to be a strong component of the social safety net. Based on the literature on organizational capacity, a model is developed to examine how service delivery at the local level is affected by organizational capacity. Surprisingly, we find few of the characteristics previously identified as important are statistically significant in this study. Even when so, the material effect is negligible. Current organizational capacity research may apply to larger nonprofits, but not to the tens of thousands of small community nonprofits, a significant limitation to the research to date. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=ORGANIZATIONAL+CAPACITY+OF+NONPROFIT+SOCIAL+SERVICE+AGENCIES&amp;rft.au=Paynter%2C+Sharon%3BBerner%2C+Marueen&amp;rft.aulast=Paynter&amp;rft.aufirst=Sharon&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.issn=10793739&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A LONGITUDINAL MODEL OF THE DYNAMICS BETWEEN HMOS' CONSUMER-FRIENDLINESS AND PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE UTILIZATION

Author: Xiao, Qian; Savage, Grant T; Zhuang, Weiling

Publication info: Journal of Health and Human Services Administration  Vol. 37, Iss. 1,  (July 2014): 76-110.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1629329991?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study aims at replicating and extending Xiao and Savage's (2008) research to understand the multidimensional aspect of HMOs distinguished by HMOs' consumer-friendliness, and their relationship to consumers' preventive care utilization. This study develops a dynamic model to consider both concurrent and time lagging effects of HMOs' consumer-friendliness. Our data analysis discloses similar relationship patterns as revealed by Xiao and Savage. Additionally, our findings reveal the time-series changes of the influence of HMOs' consumer-friendliness that either the effects of early experienced HMOs' consumer-friendliness wear out totally or HMOs' consumer-friendly characteristics on the concurrent term contain most of the explanatory power. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=A+LONGITUDINAL+MODEL+OF+THE+DYNAMICS+BETWEEN+HMOS%27+CONSUMER-FRIENDLINESS+AND+PREVENTIVE+HEALTH+CARE+UTILIZATION&amp;rft.au=Xiao%2C+Qian%3BSavage%2C+Grant+T%3BZhuang%2C+Weiling&amp;rft.aulast=Xiao&amp;rft.aufirst=Qian&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=76&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.issn=10793739&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Power; Health Maintenance Organizations; Health Care Utilization; Consumers

Classification: 6150: professional issues in social work

Title: A LONGITUDINAL MODEL OF THE DYNAMICS BETWEEN HMOS' CONSUMER-FRIENDLINESS AND PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE UTILIZATION

Correspondence author: Xiao, Qian  

Publication title: Journal of Health and Human Services Administration

Volume: 37

Issue: 1

Pages: 76-110

Number of pages: 35

Publication year: 2014

Publisher: Southern Public Administration Education Foundation Inc., Harrisburg PA

ISSN: 1079-3739

Source type: Scholarly Journals

Peer reviewed: Yes

Language of publication: English

Document type: Journal Article

Update: 2014-12-01

Accession number: 201408705

____________________________________________________________

AN EXPLORATORY STUDY OF ORGANIZATION DESIGN CONFIGURATIONS IN HEALTH CARE DELIVERY ORGANIZATIONS

Author: Sheppeck, Mick; Militello, Jack

Publication info: Journal of Health and Human Services Administration  Vol. 37, Iss. 1,  (July 2014): 4-36.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1629329995?accountid=14667

Abstract: Organizations are configurations of variables that support each other to achieve customer satisfaction. Based on Treacy and Wiersema (1995), we predicted the emergence of two configurations, one supporting a product leadership stance and one predicting the customer intimate approach from a set of 73 for profit health care clinics. In addition, we predicted the emergence of a configuration where the scores on most variables were near the mean for each variable. Using cluster analysis and discriminant function analysis, we identified three configurations: one a 'master of two' strategy, one 'stuck-in-the-middle,' and one showing scores well below the mean on most variables. The implications for organization design and manager actions in the health care industry are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.atitle=AN+EXPLORATORY+STUDY+OF+ORGANIZATION+DESIGN+CONFIGURATIONS+IN+HEALTH+CARE+DELIVERY+ORGANIZATIONS&amp;rft.au=Sheppeck%2C+Mick%3BMilitello%2C+Jack&amp;rft.aulast=Sheppeck&amp;rft.aufirst=Mick&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=37&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=4&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Health+and+Human+Services+Administration&amp;rft.issn=10793739&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Justice as a Core Virtue for Social Work Practice

Author: Donaldson, Linda Plitt; Mayer, Lynn Milgram

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 207-231.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142067?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article argues that justice should be considered as one of the core virtues to be cultivated in social work. After tracing the evolution of the term justice from ancient to contemporary times, the authors review social work conceptions of justice at both theory and practice levels, then offer ideas on how to cultivate justice as a virtue in social work students. The authors conclude with the challenges to cultivating justice and implications for research and practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Justice+as+a+Core+Virtue+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Donaldson%2C+Linda+Plitt%3BMayer%2C+Lynn+Milgram&amp;rft.aulast=Donaldson&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=207&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Virtue of Generosity

Author: Burwell, Rebecca; Huyser, Mackenzi

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 193-206.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142077?accountid=14667

Abstract: Generosity is a complex and often misunderstood virtue. Its complete meaning is rarely fully explored in the literature which leaves one to make simple assumptions about its parameters and depth. This article offers a fuller description of the virtue, tracing its history and meaning from the 16th century to today. It also explores differing views of the virtue and challenges with it. The article suggests three practices that flow from the virtue of generosity and discusses how these practices might change one's approach to his/her work as a Christian social worker. Ethical issues related to the virtue of generosity and the three suggested practices are also explored. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=The+Virtue+of+Generosity&amp;rft.au=Burwell%2C+Rebecca%3BHuyser%2C+Mackenzi&amp;rft.aulast=Burwell&amp;rft.aufirst=Rebecca&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Charity as the Heart of Social Work: A Catholic's Perspective

Author: Adams, Paul

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 137-153.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142121?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to examine the virtue of charity in its two key senses, as theological virtue (Caritas, Love) and as the virtue of aiding the poor and downtrodden. The essay examines these virtues in their historical relation to each other and to the history and current practice of social work. The factors that led to the distancing of professional social work, clinical and activist, from charity in either sense are discussed. The article uses Christian exemplars of charity as love and at the same time as aid to the downtrodden to examine how Christian social workers may grow, by grace, in charity that is integral both to their faith life and their professional practice. Benedict XVI's discussion of these issues and his advice and cautions to the Church's own social workers are analyzed as a guide to the integration of Christian love and professional helping. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Charity+as+the+Heart+of+Social+Work%3A+A+Catholic%27s+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Adams%2C+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Adams&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Adding Virtue to Faith: Strategies for Developing Character in Christian Social Work Students

Author: Milner, Marleen

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 233-253.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142156?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the relationship between a sense of calling, connectedness to God, and engagement in practices that nurture the virtues required to act upon that calling. It proposes that preparing Christians to effectively integrate faith with social work practice requires intentional pedagogical strategies to facilitate students' exploration of individual callings, the espousal of spiritual disciplines that foster virtue, and the cultivation of a community that supports spiritually integrated practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Adding+Virtue+to+Faith%3A+Strategies+for+Developing+Character+in+Christian+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Milner%2C+Marleen&amp;rft.aulast=Milner&amp;rft.aufirst=Marleen&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=233&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Introducing a Virtue Perspective for Social Work and Helping

Author: Schreiber, Jill C; Groenhout, Ruth E; Brandsen, Cheryl

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 113-135.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142192?accountid=14667

Abstract: Virtue ethics provides a helpful framework for reconciling disparate traditions such as social work and Christianity. This article begins with a summary of traditional ethical theories that are organized around agents, actions, and consequences. Virtue ethics, an agent-centered theory, is then explained more thoroughly using Alasdair MacIntyre's concepts of practice, tradition, narrative, and the good life. The role of virtue ethics in the Christian tradition is explored in the third section. It concludes by considering how a virtue perspective provides resources for addressing issues relevant to religious faith and social work. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Introducing+a+Virtue+Perspective+for+Social+Work+and+Helping&amp;rft.au=Schreiber%2C+Jill+C%3BGroenhout%2C+Ruth+E%3BBrandsen%2C+Cheryl&amp;rft.aulast=Schreiber&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Gratitude: Duty, Virtue, and Practice

Author: Vo, Charity Samantha

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 175-193.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142268?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper constructs gratitude as a virtue from an unabashedly Christian perspective. It contends that a virtue construction supplements a duty construction by emphasizing joy and generosity. Gratitude as a virtue has implications for social work practice, such as responsible stewardship, resiliency, emphasis on the gift of giving, and engagement in growth-producing relationships. The paper argues, thus, that gratitude as a virtue can create an inspirational guide to practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Gratitude%3A+Duty%2C+Virtue%2C+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Vo%2C+Charity+Samantha&amp;rft.aulast=Vo&amp;rft.aufirst=Charity&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=41&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Faith as Virtue in Social Work Practice: A Reformed Perspective

Author: Kuilema, Joseph

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 41, Iss. 2-3,  (July 2014): 155-174.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1650142301?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is concerned with how Christian faith might impact social work practice. In particular, it explores the potential resource of faith as a theological virtue, with a special emphasis on perspectives from the reformed tradition. The article explores both definitions of faith and the nature of faith as understood within a virtue perspective. Finally, it presents implications for social work practice in several areas, including global practice and dimensions of burnout. Ultimately, the paper concludes that for many Christians faith understood in these ways serves as both comfort and calling. Adapted from the source document.

Labor force participation among Asian immigrant women: Findings from the 2007 American Community Survey

Author: Lee, Sungkyu1; Zhou, Huiquan; Kim, Youngmi1 College of Social Work. The University of Tennessee-Knoxville

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (July 2014): 296-308.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018549?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using a nationally representative sample of Asian immigrant women in the USA (N = 33,032), we examined ethnic variations in labor force participation and different predictors of labor force participation among six Asian ethnic subgroups, including Chinese, Filipino, Asian Indian, Vietnamese, Korean, and Japanese. Our findings indicated that having a higher level of education, fewer children under age 5, US citizenship, a longer length of residence in the USA, and a better English proficiency were significantly related to higher rates of labor force participation among certain ethnic subgroups. The different predictors of labor force participation by ethnic subgroups were further analyzed in cultural contexts. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Labor+force+participation+among+Asian+immigrant+women%3A+Findings+from+the+2007+American+Community+Survey&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Sungkyu%3BZhou%2C+Huiquan%3BKim%2C+Youngmi&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Sungkyu&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12059

____________________________________________________________

Psychologist and Physician Interest in Telehealth Training and Referral for Mental Health Services: An Exploratory Study

Author: Perle, Jonathan G1; Burt, Jennifer; Higgins, William J1 Munroe-Meyer Institute, University of Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha, Nebraska jonperle@gmail.com

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services  Vol. 32, Iss. 3,  (July 2014): 158-185.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018698?accountid=14667

Abstract: The current study explored psychological and medical professionals' interest in videoconferencing telehealth training and mental health telehealth referral. An online survey assessed 782 participants comprised of 669 psychological (45% male, Mean Age = 47.01, SD = 16.82) and 113 medical professionals (58% male, Mean Age = 46.19, SD = 12.40). Z-test analyses indicated that although psychological professionals were statistically more interested in receiving telehealth training, both groups reported some interest. Ranked responses indicated efficacy data, ethical issues, and legal concerns as the most endorsed areas of training interest. Referral concerns were also found. Findings were discussed related to both statistical and clinical significance. Application of findings is discussed related to future work, practice, and program creation. The development of telehealth training programs will provide interested professionals with tools required for practice and may serve as an impetus to increase utilization and/or referral. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Psychologist+and+Physician+Interest+in+Telehealth+Training+and+Referral+for+Mental+Health+Services%3A+An+Exploratory+Study&amp;rft.au=Perle%2C+Jonathan+G%3BBurt%2C+Jennifer%3BHiggins%2C+William+J&amp;rft.aulast=Perle&amp;rft.aufirst=Jonathan&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=158&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2014.894488

____________________________________________________________

Financial crisis and the developmental states: A case study of Hong Kong

Author: Fung, Kwok Kin11 Department of Social Work. Hong Kong Baptist University

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (July 2014): 321-332.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018701?accountid=14667

Abstract: Studies taking a mediation perspective have highlighted how the actual impact of economic globalisation is mediated by institutions that include welfare regimes. Some have examined how the welfare systems of East Asian developmental states have changed and adapted since the Asian financial crisis of 1997/1998. Using Hong Kong as a case study, this article examines how the developmental state of Hong Kong mediated the impact of the global financial crisis of 2008, particularly on disadvantaged groups. Hong Kong's welfare regime has provided insufficient support to 'non-productive' groups despite incidents of social crisis. The government's welfare responses have been characterised by long-term strategies to improve the competitiveness of the economy, and short-term measures to boost the spending power of the general public. Measures targeted at disadvantaged groups have been piecemeal and minimal. The government's approach towards crisis management after 2008 has been similar to that taken after the 1997/1998 financial crisis. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Financial+crisis+and+the+developmental+states%3A+A+case+study+of+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Fung%2C+Kwok+Kin&amp;rft.aulast=Fung&amp;rft.aufirst=Kwok&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=321&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12060

____________________________________________________________

Job-related stress, social support, and work-family conflict among Mexican workers in a multinational company: A case study of a Korean-owned, US-branded former 'sweatshop' in Mexico

Author: Hsiao, Hsin-Yi1; Mor Barak, Michalle E1 School of Social Work. University of Southern California

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 23, Iss. 3,  (July 2014): 309-320.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660018797?accountid=14667

Abstract: Due to globalization and outsourcing of commodity production, an estimated 60 million workers are employed in the garment industry by multinational corporations, yet relatively little is known about the work-family tensions experienced by these workers. Building on role stress and job demands-resources theories, this study employed mixed methods to examine job stressors, support, and work-family conflict (WFC) in a sample of 168 Mexican workers in a multinational factory, a rarely studied and underserved population. As hypothesized, results of hierarchical regression analyses indicated that workers experienced high job stress and WFC. Social support from spouses, family, and friends increased the positive association between job stress and WFC, suggesting that culturally relevant obligations increased WFC. This study highlights the need for multinational corporations to implement culturally adaptive, family-friendly policies. Implications for social workers in multinational work organizations and for future research are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Job-related+stress%2C+social+support%2C+and+work-family+conflict+among+Mexican+workers+in+a+multinational+company%3A+A+case+study+of+a+Korean-owned%2C+US-branded+former+%27sweatshop%27+in+Mexico&amp;rft.au=Hsiao%2C+Hsin-Yi%3BMor+Barak%2C+Michalle+E&amp;rft.aulast=Hsiao&amp;rft.aufirst=Hsin-Yi&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=309&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12065

____________________________________________________________

Native American Indian Child Welfare System Change: Virtual Implementation of a Data System Based on Practice Models

Author: Scannapieco, Maria1; Iannone, Mary1 University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, Texas mscannapieco@uta.edu

Publication info: Journal of Technology in Human Services  Vol. 32, Iss. 3,  (July 2014): 220-235.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1660019886?accountid=14667

Abstract: There are 565 federally-recognized tribes who are independent sovereign nations in the United States. These tribes have varying capacity to manage and administer child welfare programs. Although many tribes have a Children's Code directing child welfare practice, standardized practice models-including procedures, policies, and subsequent forms and documentation-are not common, and management information systems are rare. A virtual implementation model informed by the Technology Acceptance Model was undertaken with three tribal child welfare agencies to design a management information system based on tribal child welfare practice models. Description and discussion of the implementation process, future research required, and lessons learned from the implementation project are presented. This article will inform Native American tribes, states who work with tribes, and rural area agencies similar in context as the tribal agencies. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.atitle=Native+American+Indian+Child+Welfare+System+Change%3A+Virtual+Implementation+of+a+Data+System+Based+on+Practice+Models&amp;rft.au=Scannapieco%2C+Maria%3BIannone%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Scannapieco&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=220&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Technology+in+Human+Services&amp;rft.issn=15228835&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228835.2014.937551

____________________________________________________________

Effects of Age Expectations on Oncology Social Workers' Clinical Judgment

Author: Conlon, Annemarie1; Choi, Namkee G1 Virginia Commonwealth University, School of Social Work, Richmond, VA, USA aconlon@vcu.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 477-490.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692283487?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This study examined the influence of oncology social workers' expectations regarding aging (ERA) and ERA with cancer (ERAC) on their clinical judgment. Methods: Oncology social workers (N = 322) were randomly assigned to one of four vignettes describing a patient with lung cancer. The vignettes were identical except for the patent's age and gender. Structural equation modeling served as the primary tool for testing the study hypotheses. Results: Significant differences were found in clinical judgment based on patient's age, and social workers' ERA and ERAC which affected diagnostic and treatment judgment for all patients. Lack of congruence was also found between the diagnosis and treatment phases of care for older patients. Emotional reaction was more often reported for the younger patient. Conclusion: Results suggest a barrier to whole patient care for all cancer patients and a need for student and practitioner training to place greater emphasis on the treatment phase of patient care. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Effects+of+Age+Expectations+on+Oncology+Social+Workers%27+Clinical+Judgment&amp;rft.au=Conlon%2C+Annemarie%3BChoi%2C+Namkee+G&amp;rft.aulast=Conlon&amp;rft.aufirst=Annemarie&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=477&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513513840

The American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare: History and Grand Challenges

Author: Barth, Richard P1; Gilmore, Grover C; Flynn, Marilyn S; Fraser, Mark W; Brekke, John S1 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD, USA rbarth@ssw.umaryland.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 495-500.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284271?accountid=14667

Abstract: Conceptualized by social work deans and actualized with the support of major social work organizations, the American Academy of Social Work and Social Welfare was established in 2009. This article describes the historical context and creation of the Academy, whose objectives include recognizing outstanding social work scholars and practitioners; informing social policy by serving as a signal scientific source of information for the social work profession and agencies seeking information; promoting the examination of social policy and the application of research to the design and development of more effective public policies, social welfare programs, and social work practice; and celebrating excellence in research, education, and practice. The Academy's 72 members have been selected using the methods of the National Academy of Science. The Academy's first substantive effort is the Grand Challenges of Social Work Initiative, designed to help transform social work science, education, and practice around visionary and achievable challenges. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+American+Academy+of+Social+Work+and+Social+Welfare%3A+History+and+Grand+Challenges&amp;rft.au=Barth%2C+Richard+P%3BGilmore%2C+Grover+C%3BFlynn%2C+Marilyn+S%3BFraser%2C+Mark+W%3BBrekke%2C+John+S&amp;rft.aulast=Barth&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=495&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514527801

Beyond Multiplication: Incorporating Importance Into Client Satisfaction Measures

Author: Hsieh, Chang-Ming11 University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, USA chsieh@uic.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 470-476.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284748?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This article brings the discussions on incorporating perceived importance across study areas into the study of client satisfaction and cautions the use of multiplicative scores (multiplying satisfaction and importance scores) as a weighting method. An alternative weighting method is provided. Method: Analyze data from a client satisfaction survey of 103 clients of a publicly funded elderly case management service unit located in a large U.S. Midwest region city. Results: The alternative weighted score correlated higher with all the global client satisfaction measures than the multiplicative score. Conclusion: Using multiplicative scores to represent global client satisfaction should be avoided. The proposed alternative weighting method is a reasonable way to incorporate perceived importance to represent global client satisfaction. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Beyond+Multiplication%3A+Incorporating+Importance+Into+Client+Satisfaction+Measures&amp;rft.au=Hsieh%2C+Chang-Ming&amp;rft.aulast=Hsieh&amp;rft.aufirst=Chang-Ming&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=470&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513511668

Pilot Evaluation of Parent and Child Enhancement Program for Disadvantaged Families

Author: Leung, Cynthia1; Tsang, Sandra; Leung, Iona1 Department of Applied Social Sciences, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Kowloon, Hong Kong ssleung@polyu.edu.hk

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 437-447.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284877?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: The present study was a pilot evaluation of the effectiveness of the Parent and Child Enhancement (PACE) program in enhancing child development for disadvantaged families with children aged 2 to 3. Method: Participants included 23 parentchild dyads who attended 2-hr sessions twice weekly for 20 weeks. Parents and children were assessed before and after program participation on child cognitive skills, learning motivation, behavior problems, parental stress, and social support. Where appropriate, teacher-reported measures were obtained. Results: The results indicated significant improvement in child cognitive scores, learning motivation, prosocial behavior, and a significant decrease in child behavior problems. Conclusion: The results provided limited initial but encouraging evidence for the effectiveness of the PACE program in promoting child outcomes. Implications for social work practice were discussed. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Pilot+Evaluation+of+Parent+and+Child+Enhancement+Program+for+Disadvantaged+Families&amp;rft.au=Leung%2C+Cynthia%3BTsang%2C+Sandra%3BLeung%2C+Iona&amp;rft.aulast=Leung&amp;rft.aufirst=Cynthia&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=437&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513512373

Evaluation of a Sexual Abuse Prevention Education for Chinese Preschoolers

Author: Zhang, Wenjing1; Chen, Jingqi; Feng, Yanan; Li, Jingyi; Liu, Chengfeng; Zhao, Xiaoxia1 Institute of Child and Adolescent Health, School of Public Health, Peking University Health Science Center, China

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 428-436.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285469?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objectives: The purpose of this study was to test the feasibility of a sexual abuse prevention education in a sample of Chinese preschool children in Beijing, China. Method: One hundred and fifty preschool children were randomly assigned to either the intervention group (N = 78) or the wait-list control group (N = 72). Children were posttested on sexual abuse prevention knowledge and self-protection skills gains. Results: Following program participation, preschool children in the intervention group demonstrated greater knowledge about sexual abuse prevention and higher levels of self-protection skills compared with children in the wait-list control group. Conclusions: Findings suggest that it is feasible to implement the sexual abuse prevention education with Chinese preschoolers. Applications and limitations of these findings are discussed. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Evaluation+of+a+Sexual+Abuse+Prevention+Education+for+Chinese+Preschoolers&amp;rft.au=Zhang%2C+Wenjing%3BChen%2C+Jingqi%3BFeng%2C+Yanan%3BLi%2C+Jingyi%3BLiu%2C+Chengfeng%3BZhao%2C+Xiaoxia&amp;rft.aulast=Zhang&amp;rft.aufirst=Wenjing&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=428&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513510409

Psychoanalytic/Psychodynamic Psychotherapy for Sexually Abused Children and Adolescents: A Systematic Review

Author: Parker, Ben1; Turner, William1 Priory Hospital, Chelmsford, UK

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 389-399.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285523?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: To assess the effectiveness of psychoanalytic/psychodynamic psychotherapy for children and adolescents who have been sexually abused. Method: The Cochrane Collaboration's criteria for data synthesis and study quality assessment were used. Electronic bibliographic databases and web searches were used to identify randomized and quasi-randomized trials comparing psychoanalytic/psychodynamic psychotherapy with treatment as usual or no treatment/waiting list control for children and adolescents up to the age of 18 who had experienced sexual abuse at any time prior to the intervention. Results: There are no randomized and quasi-randomized trials that met the inclusion criteria. Conclusion: As no eligible studies were identified, we cannot draw any conclusion as to the effectiveness of psychoanalytic/psychodynamic psychotherapy for this population. This important gap emphasizes the need for further research into the effectiveness of psychoanalytic/psychodynamic psychotherapy in this population. Directions for future research in this area are discussed. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychoanalytic%2FPsychodynamic+Psychotherapy+for+Sexually+Abused+Children+and+Adolescents%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;rft.au=Parker%2C+Ben%3BTurner%2C+William&amp;rft.aulast=Parker&amp;rft.aufirst=Ben&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=389&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514525477

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychoanalytic%2FPsychodynamic+Psychotherapy+for+Sexually+Abused+Children+and+Adolescents%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;rft.au=Parker%2C+Ben%3BTurner%2C+William&amp;rft.aulast=Parker&amp;rft.aufirst=Ben&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=389&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514525477

____________________________________________________________

The development of resilience in social work students and professionals

Author: de las Olas Palma-Garcia, Maria1; Hombrados-Mendieta, Isabel1 University of Malaga, Malaga, Spain

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 14, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 380-397.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672092?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary This study analyzes whether resilience, defined as a process rather than as a static response over time, is associated with social work. The main aim was to determine whether social work increases resilience in students and professionals during training and when practicing the profession. The sample consisted of 613 university students and professionals from Malaga (Spain). Findings The longitudinal study of social work students indicated statistically significant within-subjects differences during their university course in the components of resilience (personal competence, acceptance of self and life, and social support). Regarding professionals, the results show a positive association between years of experience and their acceptance of self and life and coping with workplace adversity. Applications Implications include the need to focus on the development of positive experiences during training and the practice of social work, such as the capacity to be resilient. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+development+of+resilience+in+social+work+students+and+professionals&amp;rft.au=de+las+Olas+Palma-Garcia%2C+Maria%3BHombrados-Mendieta%2C+Isabel&amp;rft.aulast=de+las+Olas+Palma-Garcia&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=380&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313478290

____________________________________________________________

Juvenile offenders' perceptions of probation officers as social workers in Hong Kong

Author: Chui, Wing Hong1; Chan, Heng Choon1 The University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong SAR ericchui@hku.hk

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 14, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 398-418.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672095?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary There is virtually no information available on how juvenile offenders perceive the role of Hong Kong probation officers as social workers. This study explores 113 male juvenile probationers' perceptions of their probation officers and the probation service. Drawing from the existing literature, scales are developed to measure both domains. Findings These juvenile probationers generally perceived their probation officer as relatively authoritarian or punitive. Interestingly, juveniles supervised by females perceived officers to be more authoritarian or punitive than those supervised by males. Using exploratory factor analyses, two scales, Perceptions of the Assigned Probation Officer (PAPO) and Perceptions of the Job Nature of Probation Officers (PJNPO) are developed. An ordinary least squares (OLS) regression analysis shows that probation officers are perceived to be more authoritarian or punitive by older juveniles and those supervised by females. Applications These juvenile probationers' perceptions are generally inconsistent with the operational objectives of the Hong Kong probation system, whereby probation officers are expected to be rehabilitative agents who facilitate community reintegration. Continuing civic education for young people, with an emphasis on providing accurate information about the probation system and the role of officers, would be desirable. Probation officers may also consider adopting the pro-social modeling approach that emphasizes pro-social values and behaviors in their interaction with probationers. Most importantly, a genuine working relationship between probation officers and probationers should be established. The supervision plan should be tailored to individuals' needs and capabilities, with a mutually-agreed outcome of crime desistance. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Juvenile+offenders%27+perceptions+of+probation+officers+as+social+workers+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Chui%2C+Wing+Hong%3BChan%2C+Heng+Choon&amp;rft.aulast=Chui&amp;rft.aufirst=Wing&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=398&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313478291

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Juvenile+offenders%27+perceptions+of+probation+officers+as+social+workers+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Chui%2C+Wing+Hong%3BChan%2C+Heng+Choon&amp;rft.aulast=Chui&amp;rft.aufirst=Wing&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=398&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313478291

____________________________________________________________

Exploring the role of independent organisations in care coordination for older people in England

Author: Xie, Chengqiu1; Hughes, Jane; Chester, Helen; Sutcliffe, Caroline; Challis, David1 University of Manchester, Manchester, UK Chengqiu.xie@manchester.ac.uk

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 14, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 419-438.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672101?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary Social care policies advocate the provision of coordinated care and the involvement of the independent sector in service planning and delivery. This study explores the characteristics of the independent organisations involved in care coordination for older people, the tasks undertaken, and management of the interface between the commissioning authorities and these organisations. The findings are based on semistructured telephone interviews conducted in 2009 with representatives from 25 local authorities in England regarding 40 organisations. Findings All organisations identified are voluntary in nature. They were diverse in terms of size, staffing, and history, typically undertaking care coordination for discrete user groups but few exclusively for older people. A range of care coordination activities were reported: assessment, brokerage, support planning, and monitoring and review. The extent of their involvement in these activities varied markedly. Commissioning and contracting arrangements differed; most organisations had short-term contracts. The main mechanism of contract monitoring was activity data returns; there was a lack of more detailed service evaluation. Both opportunities and challenges exist with regard to the future role of voluntary organisations in care coordination. Applications This study highlights the potential for voluntary organisations to undertake care coordination activities. To achieve this, partnership working between service commissioners and these organisations is required, and funding and support are essential for provider organisations to develop appropriate infrastructures. Information governance arrangements are required to facilitate information sharing. The potential expansion of the role of voluntary organisations and the implications for practitioners with respect to their employment prospects are explored. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+role+of+independent+organisations+in+care+coordination+for+older+people+in+England&amp;rft.au=Xie%2C+Chengqiu%3BHughes%2C+Jane%3BChester%2C+Helen%3BSutcliffe%2C+Caroline%3BChallis%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Xie&amp;rft.aufirst=Chengqiu&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=419&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313478330

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+the+role+of+independent+organisations+in+care+coordination+for+older+people+in+England&amp;rft.au=Xie%2C+Chengqiu%3BHughes%2C+Jane%3BChester%2C+Helen%3BSutcliffe%2C+Caroline%3BChallis%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Xie&amp;rft.aufirst=Chengqiu&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=419&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313478330

Promoting environmental justice through green social work practice: A key challenge for practitioners and educators

Author: Dominelli, Lena11 University of Durham, UK

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 57, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 338-345.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672178?accountid=14667

Abstract: Environmental crises associated with disasters exacerbate existing socio-economic and cultural inequalities. This article argues for the inclusion of environmental justice in contemporary social work practice as one way of promoting inclusionary social work that meets some of the challenges of the 21st century. It does so by exploring the implications of environmental degradation and its reinforcement of structural inequalities in Sri Lanka following the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami and draws on a three-year research project funded by the Economic and Social Sciences Research Council in the UK that led to the development of a multidisciplinary approach to disasters that is described in the author's recent book Green Social Work. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+environmental+justice+through+green+social+work+practice%3A+A+key+challenge+for+practitioners+and+educators&amp;rft.au=Dominelli%2C+Lena&amp;rft.aulast=Dominelli&amp;rft.aufirst=Lena&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=57&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=338&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872814524968

____________________________________________________________

Promoting social and economic equality: Social workers' contribution to social justice and social development in South Africa and Uganda

Author: Lombard, Antoinette; Twikirize, Janestic M

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 57, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 313-325.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672195?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores how social workers in South Africa (where social work is regulated by law), and Uganda (where social work is not professionally regulated), draw on the premises that social work is a human rights profession embedded in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, their respective countries' constitutions, and developmental social work to claim their role in promoting social and economic equality. The case studies from both South Africa and Uganda show that developmental social work includes social, economic and environmental development activities and that social work can become a significant role player in promoting social and economic equality through its commitment to social justice and human rights. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Promoting+social+and+economic+equality%3A+Social+workers%27+contribution+to+social+justice+and+social+development+in+South+Africa+and+Uganda&amp;rft.au=Lombard%2C+Antoinette%3BTwikirize%2C+Janestic+M&amp;rft.aulast=Lombard&amp;rft.aufirst=Antoinette&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=57&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872814525813

____________________________________________________________

The making of a civil society politics in social work: Myth and misrepresentation with the Global Agenda

Author: Gray, Mel; Webb, Stephen A

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 57, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 346-359.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672263?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article addresses 'the making' of the Global Agenda in social work by situating the process of agenda-setting itself as an object of critical reflection. It discusses the way in which the agenda positions social work as part of a global civil society network somewhat removed from grassroots social work and raises concerns about its failure to address the causes of or possible solutions to social and economic inequality. The authors deploy recent empirical research relating to object-oriented politics, particularly the 'no issue, no public' debate on political mobilization as a more viable alternative in contributing to structural change. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+making+of+a+civil+society+politics+in+social+work%3A+Myth+and+misrepresentation+with+the+Global+Agenda&amp;rft.au=Gray%2C+Mel%3BWebb%2C+Stephen+A&amp;rft.aulast=Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=Mel&amp;rft.date=2014-07-01&amp;rft.volume=57&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=346&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872814524965

____________________________________________________________

Global Agenda for Social Work and Social Development: Voices of the social work educators from Asia

Author: Nikku, Bala Raju; Pulla, Venkat

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 57, Iss. 4,  (July 2014): 373-385.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672601?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work is contextual yet increasingly internationalized. The development of Global Agenda in 2012 by the IASSW, ICSW and IFSW gave educators and practitioners an opportunity to reflect on challenges of social work education and the profession in their respective countries. The current article discusses the key factors that confront and influence social work education and practice in the Asian region. The article brings out deep-rooted perceptions amongst educators in the region. The authors endeavour to present select views of social work educators from South Asian countries and suggest possible steps to realize the four goals of Global Agenda in the context of those countries. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]
